hasDefinition: Browser Extensible Data (BED) format of sequence annotation track that strictly does not contain non-standard fields beyond the first 3 columns.
comment: Galaxy allows BED files to contain non-standard fields beyond the first 3 columns, some other implementations do not.
label: bedstrict

hasDefinition: BED file format where each feature is described by chromosome, start, end, name, score, and strand.
comment: Tab delimited data in strict BED format - no non-standard columns allowed; column count forced to 6
label: bed6

hasDefinition: A BED file where each feature is described by all twelve columns.
comment: Tab delimited data in strict BED format - no non-standard columns allowed; column count forced to 12
label: bed12

hasDefinition: Tabular format of chromosome names and sizes used by Galaxy.
comment: Galaxy allows BED files to contain non-standard fields beyond the first 3 columns, some other implementations do not.
label: chrominfo

hasDefinition: Custom Sequence annotation track format used by Galaxy.
comment: Used for tracks/track views within galaxy.
label: customtrack

hasDefinition: Color space FASTA format sequence variant.
comment: FASTA format extended for color space information.
label: csfasta

hasDefinition: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data, based on Hierarchical Data Format (HDF).
comment: An HDF5 file appears to the user as a directed graph. The nodes of this graph are the higher-level HDF5 objects that are exposed by the HDF5 APIs: Groups, Datasets, Named datatypes. Currently supported by the Python MDTraj package.
HDF5 is the new version, according to the HDF group, a completely different technology (https://support.hdfgroup.org/products/hdf4/ compared to HDF.
label: HDF5

hasDefinition: Binary file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
label: Trajectory format (binary)

hasDefinition: A versatile bitmap format.
comment: The TIFF format is perhaps the most versatile and diverse bitmap format in existence. Its extensible nature and support for numerous data compression schemes allow developers to customize the TIFF format to fit any peculiar data storage needs.
label: TIFF

hasDefinition: Standard bitmap storage format in the Microsoft Windows environment.
comment: Although it is based on Windows internal bitmap data structures, it is supported by many non-Windows and non-PC applications.
label: BMP

hasDefinition: IM is a format used by LabEye and other applications based on the IFUNC image processing library.
comment: IFUNC library reads and writes most uncompressed interchange versions of this format.
label: im

hasDefinition: Photo CD format, which is the highest resolution format for images on a CD.
comment: PCD was developed by Kodak. A PCD file contains five different resolution (ranging from low to high) of a slide or film negative. Due to it PCD is often used by many photographers and graphics professionals for high-end printed applications.
label: pcd

hasDefinition: PCX is an image file format that uses a simple form of run-length encoding. It is lossless.
label: pcx

hasDefinition: The PPM format is a lowest common denominator color image file format.
label: ppm

hasDefinition: PSD (Photoshop Document) is a proprietary file that allows the user to work with the images' individual layers even after the file has been saved.
label: psd

hasDefinition: X BitMap is a plain text binary image format used by the X Window System used for storing cursor and icon bitmaps used in the X GUI.
comment: The XBM format was replaced by XPM for X11 in 1989.
label: xbm

hasDefinition: X PixMap (XPM) is an image file format used by the X Window System, it is intended primarily for creating icon pixmaps, and supports transparent pixels.
comment: Sequence of segments with markers. Begins with byte of 0xFF and follows by marker type.
label: xpm

hasDefinition: RGB file format is the native raster graphics file format for Silicon Graphics workstations.
label: rgb

hasDefinition: The PBM format is a lowest common denominator monochrome file format. It serves as the common language of a large family of bitmap image conversion filters.
label: pbm

hasDefinition: The PGM format is a lowest common denominator grayscale file format.
comment: It is designed to be extremely easy to learn and write programs for.
label: pgm

hasDefinition: PNG is a file format for image compression.
comment: It iis expected to replace the Graphics Interchange Format (GIF).
label: PNG

hasDefinition: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) is an XML-based vector image format for two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and animation.
comment: The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.
label: SVG

hasDefinition: Sun Raster is a raster graphics file format used on SunOS by Sun Microsystems
comment: The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.
label: rast

hasDefinition: Textual report format for sequence quality for reports from sequencing machines.
label: Sequence quality report format (text)

hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences).
comment: Phred quality scores  are defined as a property which is logarithmically related to the base-calling error probabilities.
label: qual

hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.
comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
label: qualsolexa

hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.
comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
label: qualillumina

hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.
comment: For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.
label: qualsolid

hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.
label: qual454

hasDefinition: Human ENCODE peak format.
comment: Format that covers both the broad peak format and narrow peak format from ENCODE.
label: ENCODE peak format

hasDefinition: Human ENCODE narrow peak format.
comment: Format that covers both the broad peak format and narrow peak format from ENCODE.
label: ENCODE narrow peak format

hasDefinition: Human ENCODE broad peak format.
label: ENCODE broad peak format

hasDefinition: Blocked GNU Zip format.
comment: BAM files are compressed using a variant of GZIP (GNU ZIP), into a format called BGZF (Blocked GNU Zip Format).
label: bgzip

hasDefinition: TAB-delimited genome position file index format.
label: tabix

hasDefinition: Data format for graph data.
label: Graph format

hasDefinition: XML-based format used to store graph descriptions within Galaxy.
label: xgmml

hasDefinition: SIF (simple interaction file) Format - a network/pathway format used for instance in cytoscape.
label: sif

hasDefinition: MS Excel spreadsheet format consisting of a set of XML documents stored in a ZIP-compressed file.
label: xlsx

hasDefinition: Data format used by the SQLite database.
label: SQLite format

hasDefinition: Data format used by the SQLite database conformant to the Gemini schema.
label: Gemini SQLite format

hasDefinition: Format of a data index of some type.
label: Index format

hasDefinition: An index of a genome database, indexed for use by the snpeff tool.
label: snpeffdb

hasDefinition: Binary format used by MATLAB files to store workspace variables.
label: MAT

comment: Network Common Data Form (NetCDF) library is supported by AMBER MD package from version 9.
hasDefinition: Format used by netCDF software  library for writing and reading chromatography-MS data files.  Also used to store trajectory atom coordinates information, such as the ones obtained by Molecular Dynamics simulations.
label: netCDF

hasDefinition: Mascot Generic Format.  Encodes multiple MS/MS spectra in a single file.
comment: Files includes *m*/*z*, intensity pairs separated by headers; headers can contain a bit more information, including search engine instructions.
label: MGF

hasDefinition: Spectral data format file where each spectrum is written to a separate file.
comment: Each file contains one header line for the known or assumed charge and the mass of the precursor peptide ion, calculated from the measured *m*/*z* and the charge. This one line was then followed by all the *m*/*z*, intensity pairs that represent the spectrum.
label: dta

hasDefinition: Spectral data file similar to dta.
comment: Differ from .dta only in subtleties of the header line format and content and support the added feature of being able to.
label: pkl

hasDefinition: Common file format for proteomics mass spectrometric data developed at the Seattle Proteome Center/Institute for Systems Biology.
label: mzXML

hasDefinition: Open data format for the storage, exchange, and processing of peptide sequence assignments of MS/MS scans, intended to provide a common data output format for many different MS/MS search engines and subsequent peptide-level analyses.
label: pepXML

hasDefinition: Graphical Pathway Markup Language (GPML) is an XML format used for exchanging biological pathways.
label: GPML

hasDefinition: A list of k-mers and their occurences in a dataset. Can also be used as an implicit De Bruijn graph.
label: K-mer countgraph

hasDefinition: mzTab is a tab-delimited format for mass spectrometry-based proteomics and metabolomics results.
label: mzTab

hasDefinition: imzML metadata is a data format for mass spectrometry imaging metadata.
comment: imzML data are recorded in 2 files: '.imzXML' is a metadata XML file based on mzML by HUPO-PSI, and '.ibd' is a binary file containing the mass spectra. This entry is for the metadata XML file
label: imzML metadata file

hasDefinition: qcML is an XML format for quality-related data of mass spectrometry and other high-throughput measurements.
comment: The focus of qcML is towards mass spectrometry based proteomics, but the format is suitable for metabolomics and sequencing as well.
label: qcML

hasDefinition: PRIDE XML is an XML format for mass spectra, peptide and protein identifications, and metadata about a corresponding measurement, sample, experiment.
label: PRIDE XML

hasDefinition: Simulation Experiment Description Markup Language (SED-ML) is an XML format for encoding simulation setups, according to the MIASE (Minimum Information About a Simulation Experiment) requirements.
label: SED-ML

hasDefinition: Open Modeling EXchange format (OMEX) is a ZIPped format for encapsulating all information necessary for a modeling and simulation project in systems biology.
comment: An OMEX file is a ZIP container that includes a manifest file, listing the content of the archive, an optional metadata file adding information about the archive and its content, and the files describing the model. OMEX is one of the standardised formats within COMBINE (Computational Modeling in Biology Network).
label: COMBINE OMEX

hasDefinition:
The Investigation / Study / Assay (ISA) tab-delimited (TAB) format incorporates metadata from
experiments employing a combination of technologies.
comment: ISA-TAB is based on MAGE-TAB. Other than tabular, the ISA model can also be represented in RDF, and in JSON (compliable with a set of defined JSON Schemata).
label: ISA-TAB

hasDefinition: SBtab is a tabular format for biochemical network models.
label: SBtab

hasDefinition: Biological Connection Markup Language (BCML) is an XML format for biological pathways.
label: BCML

hasDefinition: Biological Dynamics Markup Language (BDML) is an XML format for quantitative data describing biological dynamics.
label: BDML

hasDefinition: Biological Expression Language (BEL) is a textual format for representing scientific findings in life sciences in a computable form.
label: BEL

hasDefinition: SBGN-ML is an XML format for Systems Biology Graphical Notation (SBGN) diagrams of biological pathways or networks.
label: SBGN-ML

hasDefinition: AGP is a tabular format for a sequence assembly (a contig, a scaffold/supercontig, or a chromosome).
label: AGP

hasDefinition: SRA archive format (SRA) is the archive format used for input to the NCBI Sequence Read Archive.
label: SRA format

hasDefinition: VDB ('vertical database') is the native format used for export from the NCBI Sequence Read Archive.
label: VDB

hasDefinition: Index file format used by the samtools package to index TAB-delimited genome position files.
label: Tabix index file format

hasDefinition: A five-column, tab-delimited table of feature locations and qualifiers for importing annotation into an existing Sequin submission (an NCBI tool for submitting and updating GenBank entries).
label: Sequin format

hasDefinition: Proprietary mass-spectrometry format of Thermo Scientific's ProteomeDiscoverer software.
comment: This format corresponds to an SQLite database, and you can look into the files with e.g. SQLiteStudio3. There are also some readers (http://doi.org/10.1021/pr2005154) and converters (http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jprot.2015.06.015) for this format available, which re-engineered the database schema, but there is no official DB schema specification of Thermo Scientific for the format.
label: MSF

hasDefinition: Data format for biodiversity data.
label: Biodiversity data format

hasDefinition: Exchange format of the Access to Biological Collections Data (ABCD) Schema; a standard for the access to and exchange of data about specimens and observations (primary biodiversity data).
label: ABCD format

hasDefinition: Tab-delimited text files of GenePattern that contain a column for each sample, a row for each gene, and an expression value for each gene in each sample.
label: GCT/Res format

hasDefinition: Mass spectrum file format from QSTAR and QTRAP instruments (ABI/Sciex).
label: WIFF format

hasDefinition: Output format used by X! series search engines that is based on the XML language BIOML.
label: X!Tandem XML

hasDefinition: Proprietary file format for mass spectrometry data from Thermo Scientific.
comment: Proprietary format for which documentation is not available.
label: Thermo RAW

hasDefinition: "Raw" result file from Mascot database search.
label: Mascot .dat file

hasDefinition: Format of peak list files from Andromeda search engine (MaxQuant) that consist of arbitrarily many spectra.
label: MaxQuant APL peaklist format

hasDefinition: Synthetic Biology Open Language (SBOL) is an XML format for the specification and exchange of biological design information in synthetic biology.
comment: SBOL introduces a standardised format for the electronic exchange of information on the structural and functional aspects of biological designs.
label: SBOL

hasDefinition: PMML uses XML to represent mining models. The structure of the models is described by an XML Schema.
comment: One or more mining models can be contained in a PMML document.
label: PMML

hasDefinition: Image file format used by the Open Microscopy Environment (OME).
comment: An OME-TIFF dataset consists of one or more files in standard TIFF or BigTIFF format, with the file extension .ome.tif or .ome.tiff, and an identical (or in the case of multiple files, nearly identical) string of OME-XML metadata embedded in the ImageDescription tag of each file's first IFD (Image File Directory). BigTIFF file extensions are also permitted, with the file extension .ome.tf2, .ome.tf8 or .ome.btf, but note these file extensions are an addition to the original specification, and software using an older version of the specification may not be able to handle these file extensions.

OME develops open-source software and data format standards for the storage and manipulation of biological microscopy data. It is a joint project between universities, research establishments, industry and the software development community.
label: OME-TIFF

hasDefinition: The LocARNA PP format combines sequence or alignment information and (respectively, single or consensus) ensemble probabilities into an PP 2.0 record.
comment: Format for multiple aligned or single sequences together with the probabilistic description of the (consensus) RNA secondary structure ensemble by probabilities of base pairs, base pair stackings, and base pairs and unpaired bases in the loop of base pairs.
label: LocARNA PP

hasDefinition: Input format used by the Database of Genotypes and Phenotypes (dbGaP).
comment: The Database of Genotypes and Phenotypes (dbGaP) is a National Institutes of Health (NIH) sponsored repository charged to archive, curate and distribute information produced by studies investigating the interaction of genotype and phenotype.
label: dbGaP format

hasDefinition: The BIological Observation Matrix (BIOM) is a format for representing biological sample by observation contingency tables in broad areas of comparative omics. The primary use of this format is to represent OTU tables and metagenome tables.
comment: BIOM is a recognised standard for the Earth Microbiome Project, and is a project supported by Genomics Standards Consortium. Supported in QIIME, Mothur, MEGAN, etc.
label: BIOM format

hasDefinition: A format for storage, exchange, and processing of protein identifications created from ms/ms-derived peptide sequence data.
comment: No human-consumable information about this format is available (see http://tools.proteomecenter.org/wiki/index.php?title=Formats:protXML).
label: protXML

hasDefinition: JSON-LD, or JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data, is a method of encoding Linked Data using JSON.
hasExactSynonym: JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data
label: JSON-LD

hasDefinition: Tabular data represented as comma-separated values in a text file.
label: CSV

hasDefinition: "Raw" result file from SEQUEST database search.
label: SEQUEST .out file

hasDefinition: XML file format for files containing information about peptide identifications from mass spectrometry data analysis carried out with OpenMS.
label: idXML

hasDefinition: Data table formatted such that it can be passed/streamed within the KNIME platform.
label: KNIME datatable format

hasDefinition: UniProtKB XML sequence features format is an XML format available for downloading UniProt entries.
label: UniProtKB XML

hasDefinition: UniProtKB RDF sequence features format is an RDF format available for downloading UniProt entries (in RDF/XML).
label: UniProtKB RDF

comment: Work in progress. 'BioXSD' belongs to the 'BioXSD|GTrack' ecosystem of generic formats. 'BioJSON' is the JSON format based on the common, unified 'BioXSD data model', a.k.a. 'BioXSD|BioJSON|BioYAML'.
hasDefinition: BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.
label: BioJSON (BioXSD)

comment: Work in progress. 'BioXSD' belongs to the 'BioXSD|GTrack' ecosystem of generic formats. 'BioYAML' is the YAML format based on the common, unified 'BioXSD data model', a.k.a. 'BioXSD|BioJSON|BioYAML'.
hasDefinition: BioYAML is a BioXSD-schema-based YAML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web APIs, human readability and editting, and object-oriented programming.
label: BioYAML

hasDefinition: BioJSON is a JSON format of single multiple sequence alignments, with their annotations, features, and custom visualisation and application settings for the Jalview workbench.
label: BioJSON (Jalview)

comment: 'GSuite' belongs to the 'BioXSD|GTrack' ecosystem of generic formats, and particular to its subset, the 'GTrack ecosystem' (GTrack, GSuite, BTrack). 'GSuite' is the tabular format for an annotated collection of individual GTrack files.
hasDefinition: GSuite is a tabular format for collections of genome or sequence feature tracks, suitable for integrative multi-track analysis. GSuite contains links to genome/sequence tracks, with additional metadata.
label: GSuite

comment: 'BTrack' belongs to the 'BioXSD|GTrack' ecosystem of generic formats, and particular to its subset, the 'GTrack ecosystem' (GTrack, GSuite, BTrack). 'BTrack' is the binary, optionally compressed HDF5-based version of the GTrack and GSuite formats.
hasDefinition: BTrack is an HDF5-based binary format for genome or sequence feature tracks and their collections, suitable for integrative multi-track analysis. BTrack is a binary, compressed alternative to the GTrack and GSuite formats.
label: BTrack

comment: Multi-Crop Passport Descriptors is a format available in 2 successive versions, V.1 (FAO/IPGRI 2001) and V.2 (FAO/Bioversity 2012).
hasDefinition: The FAO/Bioversity/IPGRI Multi-Crop Passport Descriptors (MCPD) is an international standard format for exchange of germplasm information.
label: MCPD

hasDefinition: JSON format of annotated scientific text used by PubAnnotations and other tools.
label: PubAnnotation format

hasDefinition: BioC is a standardised XML format for sharing and integrating text data and annotations.
label: BioC

hasDefinition: Native textual export format of annotated scientific text from PubTator.
label: PubTator format

hasDefinition: A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.
label: Open Annotation format

hasDefinition: A family of similar formats of text annotation, used by BRAT and other tools, known as BioNLP Shared Task format (BioNLP 2009 Shared Task on Event Extraction, BioNLP Shared Task 2011, BioNLP Shared Task 2013), BRAT format, BRAT standoff format, and similar.
label: BioNLP Shared Task format

hasDefinition: A query language (format) for structured database queries.
label: Query language

hasDefinition: SQL (Structured Query Language) is the de-facto standard query language (format of queries) for querying and manipulating data in relational databases.
label: SQL

hasDefinition: XQuery (XML Query) is a query language (format of queries) for querying and manipulating structured and unstructured data, usually in the form of XML, text, and with vendor-specific extensions for other data formats (JSON, binary, etc.).
label: XQuery

hasDefinition: SPARQL (SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language) is a semantic query language for querying and manipulating data stored in Resource Description Framework (RDF) format.
hasExactSynonym: SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language
label: SPARQL

hasDefinition: XML format for XML Schema.
label: xsd

hasDefinition: The A2M format is used as the primary format for multiple alignments of protein or nucleic-acid sequences in the SAM suite of tools. It is a small modification of FASTA format for sequences and is compatible with most tools that read FASTA.
label: XMFA

hasDefinition: The GEN file format contains genetic data and describes SNPs.
label: GEN

hasDefinition: The SAMPLE file format contains information about each individual i.e. individual IDs, covariates, phenotypes and missing data proportions, from a GWAS study.
label: SAMPLE file format

hasDefinition: SDF is one of a family of chemical-data file formats developed by MDL Information Systems; it is intended especially for structural information.
label: SDF

hasDefinition: An MDL Molfile is a file format for holding information about the atoms, bonds, connectivity and coordinates of a molecule.
label: Molfile

hasDefinition: Complete, portable representation of a SYBYL molecule. ASCII file which contains all the information needed to reconstruct a SYBYL molecule.
label: Mol2

hasDefinition: format for the LaTeX document preparation system
comment: uses the TeX typesetting program format
label: latex

hasDefinition: Tab-delimited text file format used by Eland - the read-mapping program distributed by Illumina with its sequencing analysis pipeline - which maps short Solexa sequence reads to the human reference genome.
label: ELAND format

hasDefinition: Phylip multiple alignment sequence format, less stringent than PHYLIP format.
comment: It differs from Phylip Format (format_1997) on length of the ID sequence. There no length restrictions on the ID, but whitespaces aren't allowed in the sequence ID/Name because one space separates the longest ID and the beginning of the sequence. Sequences IDs must be padded to the longest ID length.
label: Relaxed PHYLIP Interleaved

hasDefinition: Phylip multiple alignment sequence format, less stringent than PHYLIP sequential format (format_1998).
comment: It differs from Phylip sequential format (format_1997) on length of the ID sequence. There no length restrictions on the ID, but whitespaces aren't allowed in the sequence ID/Name because one space separates the longest ID and the beginning of the sequence. Sequences IDs must be padded to the longest ID length.
label: Relaxed PHYLIP Sequential

hasDefinition: Default XML format of VisANT, containing all the network information.
label: VisML

hasDefinition: GML (Graph Modeling Language) is a text file format supporting network data with a very easy syntax. It is used by Graphlet, Pajek, yEd, LEDA and NetworkX.
label: GML

hasDefinition: FASTG is a format for faithfully representing genome assemblies in the face of allelic polymorphism and assembly uncertainty.
comment: It is called FASTG, like FASTA, but the G stands for "graph".
label: FASTG

hasDefinition: Data format for raw data from a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy experiment.
hasExactSynonym: Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy data format
label: NMR data format

hasDefinition: nmrML is an MSI supported XML-based open access format for metabolomics NMR raw and processed spectral data. It is accompanies by an nmrCV (controlled vocabulary) to allow ontology-based annotations.
label: nmrML

hasDefinition: . proBAM is an adaptation of BAM (format_2572), which was extended to meet specific requirements entailed by proteomics data.
label: proBAM

hasDefinition: . proBED is an adaptation of BED (format_3003), which was extended to meet specific requirements entailed by proteomics data.
label: proBED

hasDefinition: Data format for raw microarray data.
label: Raw microarray data format

hasDefinition: GenePix Results (GPR) text file format developed by Axon Instruments that is used to save GenePix Results data.
label: GPR

hasDefinition: Binary format used by the ARB software suite
label: ARB

hasDefinition: OpenMS format for grouping features in one map or across several maps.
label: consensusXML

hasDefinition: OpenMS format for quantitation results (LC/MS features).
label: featureXML

hasDefinition: Now deprecated data format of the HUPO Proteomics Standards Initiative.  Replaced by mzML (format_3244).
label: mzData

hasDefinition: Format supported by the Tide tool for identifying peptides from tandem mass spectra.
label: TIDE TXT

hasDefinition: XML format as produced by the NCBI Blast package v2.
label: BLAST XML v2 results format

hasDefinition: Microsoft Powerpoint format.
label: pptx

hasDefinition: ibd is a data format for mass spectrometry imaging data.
comment: imzML data is recorded in 2 files: '.imzXML' is a metadata XML file based on mzML by HUPO-PSI, and '.ibd' is a binary file containing the mass spectra.
label: ibd

hasDefinition: Data format used in Natural Language Processing.
label: NLP format

hasDefinition: XML input file format for BEAST Software (Bayesian Evolutionary Analysis Sampling Trees).
label: BEAST

hasDefinition: Chado-XML format is a direct mapping of the Chado relational schema into XML.
label: Chado-XML

hasDefinition: An alignment format generated by PRANK/PRANKSTER consisting of four elements: newick, nodes, selection and model.
label: HSAML

hasDefinition: Output xml file from the InterProScan sequence analysis application.
label: InterProScan XML

hasDefinition: The KEGG Markup Language (KGML) is an exchange format of the KEGG pathway maps, which is converted from internally used KGML+ (KGML+SVG) format.
label: KGML

hasDefinition: XML format for collected entries from biobliographic databases MEDLINE and PubMed.
label: PubMed XML

hasDefinition: A set of XML compliant markup components for describing multiple sequence alignments.
label: MSAML

hasDefinition: OrthoXML is designed broadly to allow the storage and comparison of orthology data from any ortholog database. It establishes a structure for describing orthology relationships while still allowing flexibility for database-specific information to be encapsulated in the same format.
label: OrthoXML

hasDefinition: Tree structure of Protein Sequence Database Markup Language generated using Matra software.
label: PSDML

hasDefinition: SeqXML is an XML Schema to describe biological sequences, developed by the Stockholm Bioinformatics Centre.
label: SeqXML

hasDefinition: XML format for the UniParc database.
label: UniParc XML

hasDefinition: XML format for the UniRef reference clusters.
label: UniRef XML

hasDefinition: Common Workflow Language (CWL) format for description of command-line tools and workflows.
label: CWL

hasDefinition: Proprietary file format for mass spectrometry data from Waters.
comment: Proprietary format for which documentation is not available, but used by multiple tools.
label: Waters RAW

hasDefinition: A standardized file format for data exchange in mass spectrometry, initially developed for infrared spectrometry.
comment: JCAMP-DX is an ASCII based format and therefore not very compact even though it includes standards for file compression.
label: JCAMP-DX

hasDefinition: An NLP format used for annotated textual documents.
label: NLP annotation format

hasDefinition: NLP format used by a specific type of corpus (collection of texts).
label: NLP corpus format

hasDefinition: mirGFF3 is a common format for microRNA data resulting from small-RNA RNA-Seq workflows.
comment: mirGFF3 is a specialisation of GFF3; produced by small-RNA-Seq analysis workflows, usable and convertible with the miRTop API (https://mirtop.readthedocs.io/en/latest/), and consumable by tools for downstream analysis.
label: mirGFF3

hasDefinition: A "placeholder" concept for formats of annotated RNA data, including e.g. microRNA and RNA-Seq data.
label: RNA annotation format

hasDefinition: File format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
comment: Formats differ on what they are able to store (coordinates, velocities, topologies) and how they are storing it (raw, compressed, textual, binary).
label: Trajectory format

hasDefinition: Textual file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
label: Trajectory format (text)

hasDefinition: HDF is the name of a set of file formats and libraries designed to store and organize large amounts of numerical data, originally developed at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois.
comment: HDF is currently supported by many commercial and non-commercial software platforms such as Java, MATLAB/Scilab, Octave, Python and R.
label: HDF

hasDefinition: PCAZip format is a binary compressed file to store atom coordinates based on Essential Dynamics (ED) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA).
comment: The compression is made projecting the Cartesian snapshots collected along the trajectory into an orthogonal space defined by the most relevant eigenvectors obtained by diagonalization of the covariance matrix (PCA). In the compression/decompression process, part of the original information is lost, depending on the final number of eigenvectors chosen. However, with a reasonable choice of the set of eigenvectors the compression typically reduces the trajectory file to less than one tenth of their original size with very acceptable loss of information. Compression with PCAZip can only be applied to unsolvated structures.
label: PCAzip

hasDefinition: Portable binary format for trajectories produced by GROMACS package.
comment: XTC uses the External Data Representation (xdr) routines for writing and reading data which were created for the Unix Network File System (NFS). XTC files use a reduced precision (lossy) algorithm which works multiplying the coordinates by a scaling factor (typically 1000), so converting them to pm (GROMACS standard distance unit is nm). This allows an integer rounding of the values. Several other tricks are performed, such as making use of atom proximity information: atoms close in sequence are usually close in space (e.g. water molecules). That makes XTC format the most efficient in terms of disk usage, in most cases reducing by a factor of 2 the size of any other binary trajectory format.
label: XTC

hasDefinition: Trajectory Next Generation (TNG) is a format for storage of molecular simulation data. It is designed and implemented by the GROMACS development group, and it is called to be the substitute of the XTC format.
comment: Fully architecture-independent format, regarding both endianness and the ability to mix single/double precision trajectories and I/O libraries. Self-sufficient, it should not require any other files for reading, and all the data should be contained in a single file for easy transport. Temporal compression of data, improving the compression rate of the previous XTC format. Possibility to store meta-data with information about the simulation. Direct access to a particular frame. Efficient parallel I/O.
label: TNG

hasDefinition: The XYZ chemical file format is widely supported by many programs, although many slightly different XYZ file formats coexist (Tinker XYZ, UniChem XYZ, etc.). Basic information stored for each atom in the system are x, y and z coordinates and atom element/atomic number.
comment: XYZ files are structured in this way:  First line contains the number of atoms in the file.  Second line contains a title, comment, or filename. Remaining lines contain atom information. Each line starts with the element symbol, followed by x, y and z coordinates in angstroms separated by whitespace. Multiple molecules or frames can be contained within one file, so it supports trajectory storage. XYZ files can be directly represented by a molecular viewer, as they contain all the basic information needed to build the 3D model.
label: XYZ

hasDefinition: AMBER trajectory (also called mdcrd), with 10 coordinates per line and format F8.3 (fixed point notation with field width 8 and 3 decimal places).
label: mdcrd

hasDefinition: Format of topology files; containing the static information of a structure molecular system that is needed for a molecular simulation.
comment: Many different file formats exist describing structural molecular topology. Tipically, each MD package or simulation software works with their own implementation (e.g. GROMACS top, CHARMM psf, AMBER prmtop).
label: Topology format

hasDefinition: GROMACS MD package top textual files define an entire structure system topology, either directly, or by including itp files.
comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
label: GROMACS top

hasDefinition: AMBER Prmtop file (version 7) is a structure topology text file divided in several sections designed to be parsed easily using simple Fortran code. Each section contains particular topology information, such as atom name, charge, mass, angles, dihedrals, etc.
comment: It can be modified manually, but as the size of the system increases, the hand-editing becomes increasingly complex. AMBER Parameter-Topology file format is used extensively by the AMBER software suite and is referred to as the Prmtop file for short.

version 7 is written to distinguish it from old versions of AMBER Prmtop. Similarly to HDF5, it is a completely different format, according to AMBER group: a drastic change to the file format occurred with the 2004 release of Amber 7 (http://ambermd.org/prmtop.pdf)
label: AMBER top

hasDefinition: X-Plor Protein Structure Files (PSF) are structure topology files used by NAMD and CHARMM molecular simulations programs. PSF files contain six main sections of interest: atoms, bonds, angles, dihedrals, improper dihedrals (force terms used to maintain planarity) and cross-terms.
comment: The high similarity in the functional form of the two potential energy functions used by AMBER and CHARMM force-fields gives rise to the possible use of one force-field within the other MD engine. Therefore, the conversion of PSF files to AMBER Prmtop format is possible with the use of AMBER chamber (CHARMM - AMBER) program.
label: PSF

hasDefinition: GROMACS itp files (include topology) contain structure topology information, and are tipically included in GROMACS topology files (GROMACS top). Itp files are used to define individual (or multiple) components of a topology as a separate file. This is particularly useful if there is a molecule that is used frequently, and also reduces the size of the system topology file, splitting it in different parts.
comment: GROMACS itp files are used also to define position restrictions on the molecule, or to define the force field parameters for a particular ligand.
label: GROMACS itp

hasDefinition: Format of force field parameter files, which store the set of parameters (charges, masses, radii, bond lengths, bond dihedrals, etc.) that are essential for the proper description and simulation of a molecular system.
comment: Many different file formats exist describing force field parameters. Tipically, each MD package or simulation software works with their own implementation (e.g. GROMACS itp, CHARMM rtf, AMBER off / frcmod).
label: FF parameter format

hasDefinition: Scripps Research Institute BinPos format is a binary formatted file to store atom coordinates.
comment: It is basically a translation of the ASCII atom coordinate format to binary code. The only additional information stored is a magic number that identifies the BinPos format and the number of atoms per snapshot. The remainder is the chain of coordinates binary encoded. A drawback of this format is its architecture dependency. Integers and floats codification depends on the architecture, thus it needs to be converted if working in different platforms (little endian, big endian).
label: BinPos

hasDefinition: AMBER coordinate/restart file with 6 coordinates per line and decimal format F12.7 (fixed point notation with field width 12 and 7 decimal places)
label: RST

hasDefinition: Format of CHARMM Residue Topology Files (RTF), which define groups by including the atoms, the properties of the group, and bond and charge information.
comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
label: CHARMM rtf

hasDefinition: AMBER frcmod (Force field Modification) is a file format to store any modification to the standard force field needed for a particular molecule to be properly represented in the simulation.
label: AMBER frcmod

hasDefinition: AMBER Object File Format library files (OFF library files) store residue libraries (forcefield residue parameters).
label: AMBER off

hasDefinition: MReData is a text based data standard for processed NMR data. It is relying on SDF molecule data and allows to store assignments of NMR peaks to molecule features.  The NMR-extracted data (or "NMReDATA") includes: Chemical shift,scalar coupling, 2D correlation, assignment, etc.
comment: NMReData is a text based data standard for processed NMR data. It is relying on SDF molecule data and allows to store assignments of NMR peaks to molecule features. The NMR-extracted data (or "NMReDATA") includes: Chemical shift,scalar coupling, 2D correlation, assignment, etc. Find more in the paper at D. Jeannerat, Magn. Reson. in Chem., 2017, 55, 7-14.
label: NMReDATA

hasDefinition: BpForms is a string format for concretely representing the primary structures of biopolymers, including DNA, RNA, and proteins that include non-canonical nucleic and amino acids. See https://www.bpforms.org for more information.
label: BpForms

comment: The first 4 bytes of any trr file containing 1993. See https://github.com/galaxyproject/galaxy/pull/6597/files#diff-409951594551183dbf886e24de6cb129R760
hasDefinition: Format of trr files that contain the trajectory of a simulation experiment used by GROMACS.
label: trr

hasDefinition: Mash sketch is a format for sequence / sequence checksum information. To make a sketch, each k-mer in a sequence is hashed, which creates a pseudo-random identifier. By sorting these hashes, a small subset from the top of the sorted list can represent the entire sequence.
label: msh

hasDefinition: The Loom file format is based on HDF5, a standard for storing large numerical datasets. The Loom format is designed to efficiently hold large omics datasets. Typically, such data takes the form of a large matrix of numbers, along with metadata for the rows and columns.
label: Loom

hasDefinition: The Zarr format is an implementation of chunked, compressed, N-dimensional arrays for storing data.
label: Zarr

hasDefinition: The Matrix Market matrix (MTX) format stores numerical or pattern matrices in a dense (array format) or sparse (coordinate format) representation.
label: MTX

hasDefinition: BcForms is a format for abstractly describing the molecular structure (atoms and bonds) of macromolecular complexes as a collection of subunits and crosslinks. Each subunit can be described with BpForms (http://edamontology.org/format_3909) or SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301). BcForms uses an ontology of crosslinks to abstract the chemical details of crosslinks from the descriptions of complexes (see https://bpforms.org/crosslink.html).
comment: BcForms is related to http://edamontology.org/format_3909. (BcForms uses BpForms to describe subunits which are DNA, RNA, or protein polymers.) However, that format isn't the parent of BcForms. BcForms is similarly related to SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301).
label: BcForms

hasDefinition: N-Quads is a line-based, plain text format for encoding an RDF dataset. It includes information about the graph each triple belongs to.
comment: N-Quads should not be confused with N-Triples which does not contain graph information.
label: N-Quads

hasDefinition: Vega is a visualization grammar, a declarative language for creating, saving, and sharing interactive visualization designs. With Vega, you can describe the visual appearance and interactive behavior of a visualization in a JSON format, and generate web-based views using Canvas or SVG.
label: Vega

hasDefinition: Vega-Lite is a high-level grammar of interactive graphics. It provides a concise JSON syntax for rapidly generating visualizations to support analysis. Vega-Lite specifications can be compiled to Vega specifications.
label: Vega-lite

hasDefinition: A model description language for computational neuroscience.
label: NeuroML

hasDefinition: BioNetGen is a format for the specification and simulation of rule-based models of biochemical systems, including signal transduction, metabolic, and genetic regulatory networks.
label: BNGL

hasDefinition: A Docker image is a file, comprised of multiple layers, that is used to execute code in a Docker container. An image is essentially built from the instructions for a complete and executable version of an application, which relies on the host OS kernel.
label: Docker image format

hasDefinition: Graphical Fragment Assembly captures sequence graphs as the product of an assembly, a representation of variation in genomes, splice graphs in genes, or even overlap between reads from long-read sequencing technology.
label: GFA 1

hasDefinition: Graphical Fragment Assembly captures sequence graphs as the product of an assembly, a representation of variation in genomes, splice graphs in genes, or even overlap between reads from long-read sequencing technology.
label: GFA 2

hasDefinition: ObjTables is a toolkit for creating re-usable datasets that are both human and machine-readable, combining the ease of spreadsheets (e.g., Excel workbooks) with the rigor of schemas (classes, their attributes, the type of each attribute, and the possible relationships between instances of classes). ObjTables consists of a format for describing schemas for spreadsheets, numerous data types for science, a syntax for indicating the class and attribute represented by each table and column in a workbook, and software for using schemas to rigorously validate, merge, split, compare, and revision datasets.
label: ObjTables

hasDefinition: The CONTIG format used for output of the SOAPdenovo alignment program. It contains contig sequences generated without using mate pair information.
label: CONTIG

hasDefinition: WEGO native format used by the Web Gene Ontology Annotation Plot application.   Tab-delimited format with gene names and others GO IDs (columns) with one annotation record per line.
label: WEGO

hasDefinition: Tab-delimited format for gene expression levels table, calculated as Reads Per Kilobase per Million (RPKM) mapped reads.
comment: For example a 1kb transcript with 1000 alignments in a sample of 10 million reads (out of which 8 million reads can be mapped) will have RPKM = 1000/(1 * 8) = 125
label: RPKM

hasDefinition: TAR archive file format generated by the Unix-based utility tar.
comment: For example a 1kb transcript with 1000 alignments in a sample of 10 million reads (out of which 8 million reads can be mapped) will have RPKM = 1000/(1 * 8) = 125
label: TAR format

hasDefinition: The CHAIN format describes a pairwise alignment that allow gaps in both sequences simultaneously and is used by the UCSC Genome Browser.
label: CHAIN

hasDefinition: The NET file format is used to describe the data that underlie the net alignment annotations in the UCSC Genome Browser.
label: NET

hasDefinition: Format of QMAP files generated for methylation data from an internal BGI pipeline.
label: QMAP

hasDefinition: An emerging format for high-level Galaxy workflow description.
label: gxformat2

hasDefinition: The proprietary native video format of various Microsoft programs such as Windows Media Player.
label: WMV

hasDefinition: ZIP is an archive file format that supports lossless data compression.
comment: A ZIP file may contain one or more files or directories that may have been compressed.
label: ZIP format

hasDefinition: Zeiss' proprietary image format based on TIFF.
comment: LSM files are the default data export for the Zeiss LSM series confocal microscopes (e.g. LSM 510, LSM 710). In addition to the image data, LSM files contain most imaging settings.
label: LSM

hasDefinition: GNU zip compressed file format common to Unix-based operating systems.
label: GZIP format

hasDefinition: Audio Video Interleaved (AVI) format is a multimedia container format for AVI files, that allows synchronous audio-with-video playback.
label: AVI

hasDefinition: A declaration file format for UCSC browsers track dataset display charateristics.
label: TrackDB

hasDefinition: Compact Idiosyncratic Gapped Alignment Report format is a compressed (run-length encoded) pairwise alignment format. It is useful for representing long (e.g. genomic) pairwise alignments.
label: CIGAR format

hasDefinition: STL is a file format native to the stereolithography CAD software created by 3D Systems.  The format is used to save and share surface-rendered 3D images and also for 3D printing.
label: Stereolithography format

hasDefinition: U3D (Universal 3D) is a compressed file format and data structure for 3D computer graphics. It contains 3D model information such as triangle meshes, lighting, shading, motion data, lines and points with color and structure.
label: U3D

hasDefinition: Bitmap image format used for storing textures.
comment: Texture files can create the appearance of different surfaces and can be applied to both 2D and 3D objects. Note the file extension .tex is also used for LaTex documents which are a completely different format and they are NOT interchangable.
label: Texture file format

hasDefinition: Format for scripts writtenin Python - a widely used high-level programming language for general-purpose programming.
label: Python script

hasDefinition: A digital multimedia container format most commonly used to store video and audio.
label: MPEG-4

hasDefinition: Format for scripts written in Perl - a family of high-level, general-purpose, interpreted, dynamic programming languages.
label: Perl script

hasDefinition: Format for scripts written in the R language - an open source programming language and software environment for statistical computing and graphics that is supported by the R Foundation for Statistical Computing.
label: R script

hasDefinition: A file format for making dynamic documents (R Markdown scripts) with the R language.
label: R markdown

hasDefinition: An open file format from the Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative (NIfTI) commonly used to store brain imaging data obtained using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) methods.
label: NIFTI format

hasDefinition: Format used by Python pickle module for serializing and de-serializing a Python object structure.
label: pickle

hasDefinition: The standard binary file format used by NumPy - a fundamental package for scientific computing with Python - for persisting a single arbitrary NumPy array on disk. The format stores all of the shape and dtype information necessary to reconstruct the array correctly.
label: NumPy format

hasDefinition: Format of repertoire (archive) files that can be read by SimToolbox (a MATLAB toolbox for structured illumination fluorescence microscopy) or alternatively extracted with zip file archiver software.
label: SimTools repertoire file format

hasDefinition: A configuration file used by various programs to store settings that are specific to their respective software.
label: Configuration file format

hasDefinition: Format used by the Zstandard real-time compression algorith.
label: Zstandard format

hasDefinition: The file format for MATLAB scripts or functions.
label: MATLAB script

hasDefinition: A function that processes a set of inputs and results in a set of outputs, or associates arguments (inputs) with values (outputs).
comment: Special cases are: a) An operation that consumes no input (has no input arguments). Such operation is either a constant function, or an operation depending only on the underlying state. b) An operation that may modify the underlying state but has no output. c) The singular-case operation with no input or output, that still may modify the underlying state.
label: Operation

hasDefinition: Search or query a data resource and retrieve entries and / or annotation.
label: Query and retrieval

hasDefinition: Basic (non-analytical) operations of some data, either a file or equivalent entity in memory, such that the same basic type of data is consumed as input and generated as output.
label: Data handling

hasDefinition: Search database to retrieve all relevant references to a particular entity or entry.
label: Data retrieval (database cross-reference)

hasDefinition: Annotate an entity (typically a biological or biomedical database entity) with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
comment: This is a broad concept and is used a placeholder for other, more specific concepts.
label: Annotation

hasDefinition: Generate an index of (typically a file of) biological data.
label: Indexing

hasDefinition: Analyse an index of biological data.
label: Data index analysis

hasDefinition: Retrieve basic information about a molecular sequence.
label: Annotation retrieval (sequence)

hasDefinition: Generate a molecular sequence by some means.
label: Sequence generation

hasDefinition: Analyse one or more known molecular sequences.
label: Sequence analysis

hasDefinition: Construct some data entity.
comment: For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.
label: Generation

hasDefinition: Edit or change a molecular sequence, either randomly or specifically.
label: Sequence editing

hasDefinition: Edit a data entity, either randomly or specifically.
label: Editing

hasDefinition: Merge two or more (typically overlapping) molecular sequences.
label: Sequence merging

hasDefinition: Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.
label: Sequence conversion

hasDefinition: Convert a data set from one form to another.
label: Conversion

hasDefinition: Calculate sequence complexity, for example to find low-complexity regions in sequences.
label: Sequence complexity calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate character or word composition or frequency of a molecular sequence.
label: Sequence composition calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate sequence ambiguity, for example identity regions in protein or nucleotide sequences with many ambiguity codes.
label: Sequence ambiguity calculation

hasDefinition: Mathematical determination of the value of something, typically a properly of a  molecule.
label: Calculation

hasDefinition: Find and/or analyse repeat sequences in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
comment: Repeat sequences include tandem repeats, inverted or palindromic repeats, DNA microsatellites (Simple Sequence Repeats or SSRs), interspersed repeats, maximal duplications and reverse, complemented and reverse complemented repeats etc. Repeat units can be exact or imperfect, in tandem or dispersed, of specified or unspecified length.
label: Repeat sequence analysis

hasDefinition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).
label: Sequence motif discovery

hasDefinition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.
comment: Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.
label: Sequence feature detection

hasDefinition: Analyse molecular sequence motifs.
label: Sequence motif analysis

hasDefinition: Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).
label: Sequence motif recognition

hasDefinition: Find motifs shared by molecular sequences.
label: Sequence motif comparison

hasDefinition: Compare two or more molecular sequences.
label: Sequence comparison

hasDefinition: Analyse the sequence, conformational or physicochemical properties of transcription regulatory elements in DNA sequences.
comment: For example transcription factor binding sites (TFBS) analysis to predict accessibility of DNA to binding factors.
label: Transcription regulatory sequence analysis

hasDefinition: Identify common, conserved (homologous) or synonymous transcriptional regulatory motifs (transcription factor binding sites).
label: Conserved transcription regulatory sequence identification

hasDefinition: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein from processing a protein (3D) structure.
label: Protein property calculation (from structure)

hasDefinition: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.
comment: Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.
label: Simulation analysis

hasDefinition: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence, from processing a protein sequence or 3D structure.
comment: This includes methods to render and visualise the properties of a protein sequence, and a residue-level search for properties such as solvent accessibility, hydropathy, secondary structure, ligand-binding etc.
label: Protein property calculation

hasDefinition: Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).
comment: This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.
label: Structural motif discovery

hasDefinition: Analyse protein structural data.
label: Protein structure analysis

hasDefinition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in proteins from analysing protein sequences or structures.
comment: Features includes functional sites or regions, secondary structure, structural domains and so on. Methods might use fingerprints, motifs, profiles, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment etc to provide a mapping of a query protein sequence to a discriminatory element. This includes methods that search a secondary protein database (Prosite, Blocks, ProDom, Prints, Pfam etc.) to assign a protein sequence(s) to a known protein family or group.
label: Protein feature detection

hasDefinition: Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).
label: Protein domain recognition

hasDefinition: Analyse the architecture (spatial arrangement of secondary structure) of protein structure(s).
label: Protein architecture analysis

hasDefinition: Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).
label: Residue interaction calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.
label: Protein geometry calculation

hasDefinition: Predict, recognise, detect or identify some properties of a biomolecule.
label: Prediction and recognition

hasDefinition: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.
comment: Immunological system are cellular or humoral. In vaccine design to induces a cellular immune response, methods must search for antigens that can be recognized by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules present in T lymphocytes.  If a humoral response is required, antigens for B cells must be identified.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.
label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction

hasDefinition: Predict the biological or biochemical role of a protein, or other aspects of a protein function.
comment: For functional properties that can be mapped to a sequence, use 'Sequence feature detection (protein)' instead.
label: Protein function prediction

hasDefinition: Extract a sequence feature table from a sequence database entry.
label: Data retrieval (feature table)

hasDefinition: Query the features (in a feature table) of molecular sequence(s).
label: Feature table query

hasDefinition: Compare the feature tables of two or more molecular sequences.
label: Sequence feature comparison

hasDefinition: Compare two or more things to identify similarities.
label: Comparison

hasDefinition: Display basic information about a sequence alignment.
label: Data retrieval (sequence alignment)

hasDefinition: Analyse a molecular sequence alignment.
label: Sequence alignment analysis

hasDefinition: Compare (typically by aligning) two molecular sequence alignments.
comment: See also 'Sequence profile alignment'.
label: Sequence alignment comparison

hasDefinition: Convert a molecular sequence alignment from one type to another (for example amino acid to coding nucleotide sequence).
label: Sequence alignment conversion

hasDefinition: Edit, convert or otherwise change a molecular sequence alignment, either randomly or specifically.
label: Sequence alignment editing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) physicochemical property data of nucleic acids.
label: Nucleic acid property processing

hasDefinition: Calculate or predict physical or chemical properties of nucleic acid molecules, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence.
label: Nucleic acid property calculation

hasDefinition: Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.
label: Alternative splicing prediction

hasDefinition: Predict, analyse, characterize or model splice sites, splicing events and so on, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.
label: Splicing analysis

hasDefinition: Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.
comment: Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.
label: Frameshift detection

hasDefinition: Detect errors in DNA sequences generated from sequencing projects).
label: Sequencing error detection

hasDefinition: Detect, identify and map mutations, such as single nucleotide polymorphisms, short indels and structural variants, in multiple DNA sequences. Typically the alignment and comparison of the fluorescent traces produced by DNA sequencing hardware, to study genomic alterations.
comment: Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.
Somatic variant calling is the detection of variations established in somatic cells and hence not inherited as a germ line variant.
Variant detection
label: Variant calling

hasDefinition: Detect vector sequences in nucleotide sequence, typically by comparison to a set of known vector sequences.
label: Vector sequence detection

hasDefinition: Predict, recognise and identify features in nucleotide sequences such as functional sites or regions, typically by scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.
comment: Methods typically involve scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.

This is placeholder but does not comprehensively include all child concepts - please inspect other concepts under "Nucleic acid sequence analysis" for example "Gene prediction", for other feature detection operations.
label: Nucleic acid feature detection

hasDefinition: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.
comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.
label: Protein secondary structure prediction

hasDefinition: Analyse protein secondary structure data.
label: Protein secondary structure analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse a protein sequence (using methods that are only applicable to protein sequences).
label: Protein sequence analysis

hasDefinition: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).
comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.
label: Protein super-secondary structure prediction

hasDefinition: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
label: Transmembrane protein prediction

hasDefinition: Analyse transmembrane protein(s), typically by processing sequence and / or structural data, and write an informative report for example about the protein and its transmembrane domains / regions.
comment: Use this (or child) concept for analysis of transmembrane domains (buried and exposed faces), transmembrane helices, helix topology, orientation, inter-helical contacts, membrane dipping (re-entrant) loops and other secondary structure etc. Methods might use pattern discovery, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment, structural profiles, amino acid property analysis, comparison to known domains or some combination (hybrid methods).
label: Transmembrane protein analysis

hasDefinition: Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.
comment: This excludes non-analytical methods that read and write the same basic type of data (for that, see 'Data handling').
label: Analysis

hasDefinition: Predict tertiary structure of a molecular (biopolymer) sequence.
label: Structure prediction

hasDefinition: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.
comment: Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.
label: Residue contact prediction

hasDefinition: Analyse experimental protein-protein interaction data from for example yeast two-hybrid analysis, protein microarrays, immunoaffinity chromatography followed by mass spectrometry, phage display etc.
label: Protein interaction raw data analysis

hasDefinition: Identify or predict protein-protein interactions, interfaces, binding sites etc in protein sequences.
label: Protein-protein interaction prediction (from protein sequence)

hasDefinition: Identify or predict protein-protein interactions, interfaces, binding sites etc in protein structures.
label: Protein-protein interaction prediction (from protein structure)

hasDefinition: Analyse a network of protein interactions.
label: Protein interaction network analysis

comment: Includes analysis of raw experimental protein-protein interaction data from for example yeast two-hybrid analysis, protein microarrays, immunoaffinity chromatography followed by mass spectrometry, phage display etc.
hasDefinition: Analyse the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
label: Protein-protein interaction analysis

hasDefinition: Generate, process or analyse a biological network.
label: Network analysis

hasDefinition: Compare two or more biological pathways or networks.
label: Pathway or network comparison

hasDefinition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
label: RNA secondary structure prediction

hasDefinition: Predict structure of DNA or RNA.
comment: Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.
label: Nucleic acid structure prediction

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) RNA secondary structure data.
label: RNA secondary structure analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
label: Nucleic acid folding analysis

hasDefinition: Model or simulate some biological entity or system, typically using mathematical techniques including  dynamical systems, statistical models, differential equations, and game theoretic models.
label: Modelling and simulation

hasDefinition: Analyse nucleic acid tertiary structural data.
label: Nucleic acid structure analysis

hasDefinition: Retrieve information on restriction enzymes or restriction enzyme sites.
label: Data retrieval (restriction enzyme annotation)

hasDefinition: Identify genetic markers in DNA sequences.
comment: A genetic marker is any DNA sequence of known chromosomal location that is associated with and specific to a particular gene or trait. This includes short sequences surrounding a SNP, Sequence-Tagged Sites (STS) which are well suited for PCR amplification, a longer minisatellites sequence etc.
label: Genetic marker identification

hasDefinition: Generate a genetic (linkage) map of a DNA sequence (typically a chromosome) showing the relative positions of genetic markers based on estimation of non-physical distances.
comment: Mapping involves ordering genetic loci along a chromosome and estimating the physical distance between loci. A genetic map shows the relative (not physical) position of known genes and genetic markers.
This includes mapping of the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits (functional mapping), e.g. by characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).
label: Genetic mapping

hasDefinition: Analyse genetic linkage.
comment: For example, estimate how close two genes are on a chromosome by calculating how often they are transmitted together to an offspring, ascertain whether two genes are linked and parental linkage, calculate linkage map distance etc.
label: Linkage analysis

hasDefinition: Generate a map of a DNA sequence annotated with positional or non-positional features of some type.
label: DNA mapping

hasDefinition: Analyse a nucleic acid sequence (using methods that are only applicable to nucleic acid sequences).
label: Nucleic acid sequence analysis

hasDefinition: Calculate codon usage statistics and create a codon usage table.
label: Codon usage table generation

hasDefinition: Analyse codon usage in molecular sequences or process codon usage data (e.g. a codon usage table).
label: Codon usage analysis

hasDefinition: Compare two or more codon usage tables.
label: Codon usage table comparison

hasDefinition: Compare two or more nucleic acids to identify similarities.
label: Nucleic acid comparison

hasDefinition: Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.
label: Base position variability plotting

hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.
label: Sequence visualisation

hasDefinition: Find exact character or word matches between molecular sequences without full sequence alignment.
label: Sequence word comparison

hasDefinition: Calculate a sequence distance matrix or otherwise estimate genetic distances between molecular sequences.
label: Sequence distance matrix generation

hasDefinition: Compare two or more molecular sequences, identify and remove redundant sequences based on some criteria.
label: Sequence redundancy removal

hasDefinition: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
comment: The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.
label: Sequence clustering

hasDefinition: Group together some data entities on the basis of similarities such that entities in the same group (cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups (clusters).
label: Clustering

comment: Includes methods that align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments): ethods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.  See also 'Sequence alignment comparison'.
See also "Read mapping"
hasDefinition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.
label: Sequence alignment

hasDefinition: Compare two or more entities, typically the sequence or structure (or derivatives) of macromolecules, to identify equivalent subunits.
label: Alignment

hasDefinition: Align two or more molecular sequences of different types (for example genomic DNA to EST, cDNA or mRNA).
label: Hybrid sequence alignment construction

hasDefinition: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.
label: Structure-based sequence alignment

comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
label: Structure alignment

hasDefinition: Analyse known molecular tertiary structures.
label: Structure analysis

hasDefinition: Compare two or more molecular tertiary structures.
label: Structure comparison

hasDefinition: Generate some type of sequence profile (for example a hidden Markov model) from a sequence alignment.
label: Sequence profile generation

hasDefinition: Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.
label: 3D profile generation

hasDefinition: Align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments).
label: Profile-profile alignment

hasDefinition: Align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments).
label: 3D profile-to-3D profile alignment

hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
label: Sequence profile alignment

hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment).
label: Sequence-to-3D-profile alignment

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
label: Protein threading

hasDefinition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
label: Fold recognition

hasDefinition: Compare two or more proteins (or some aspect) to identify similarities.
label: Protein comparison

hasDefinition: Search for and retrieve data concerning or describing some core data, as distinct from the primary data that is being described.
comment: This includes documentation, general information and other metadata on entities such as databases, database entries and tools.
label: Metadata retrieval

hasDefinition: Query scientific literature, in search for articles, article data, concepts, named entities, or for statistics.
label: Literature search

hasDefinition: Search a database (or other data resource) with a supplied query and retrieve entries (or parts of entries) that are similar to the query.
comment: Typically the query is compared to each entry and high scoring matches (hits) are returned. For example, a BLAST search of a sequence database.
label: Database search

hasDefinition: Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.
label: Text mining

hasDefinition: Perform in-silico (virtual) PCR.
label: Virtual PCR

hasDefinition: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.
hasNarrowSynonym: PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)
comment: Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.

This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling,  for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs),  for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.
label: PCR primer design

hasDefinition: Predict oligonucleotide primers or probes.
label: Primer and probe design

hasDefinition: Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.
label: Microarray probe design

hasDefinition: Design a biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure) with specific properties.
label: Design

hasDefinition: Combine (align and merge) overlapping fragments of a DNA sequence to reconstruct the original sequence.
comment: For example, assemble overlapping reads from paired-end sequencers into contigs (a contiguous sequence corresponding to read overlaps). Or assemble contigs, for example ESTs and genomic DNA fragments, depending on the detected fragment overlaps.
label: Sequence assembly

hasDefinition: Standardize or normalize microarray data.
label: Microarray data standardisation and normalisation

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) SAGE, MPSS or SBS experimental data.
label: Sequencing-based expression profile data processing

hasDefinition: Perform cluster analysis of expression data to identify groups with similar expression profiles, for example by clustering.
label: Expression profile clustering

hasDefinition: Comparison of expression profiles.
label: Expression profile comparison

hasDefinition: The measurement of the activity (expression) of multiple genes in a cell, tissue, sample etc., in order to get an impression of biological function.
comment: Gene expression profiling generates some sort of gene expression profile, for example from microarray data.
label: Gene expression profiling

comment: Metagenomic inference is the profiling of phylogenetic marker genes in order to predict metagenome function.
hasDefinition: Process (read and/or write) expression data from experiments measuring molecules (e.g. omics data), including analysis of one or more expression profiles, typically to interpret them in functional terms.
label: Expression analysis

hasDefinition: Interpret (in functional terms) and annotate gene expression data.
label: Functional profiling

hasDefinition: Analyse EST or cDNA sequences.
comment: For example, identify full-length cDNAs from EST sequences or detect potential EST antisense transcripts.
label: EST and cDNA sequence analysis

hasDefinition: Identify and select targets for protein structural determination.
comment: Methods will typically navigate a graph of protein families of known structure.
label: Structural genomics target selection

comment: Includes secondary structure assignment from circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopic data, and from protein coordinate data.
