hasDefinition: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.
label: Protein secondary structure assignment

hasDefinition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.
label: Protein structure assignment

hasDefinition: Evaluate the quality or correctness a protein three-dimensional model.
comment: Model validation might involve checks for atomic packing, steric clashes (bumps), volume irregularities, agreement with electron density maps, number of amino acid residues, percentage of residues with missing or bad atoms, irregular Ramachandran Z-scores, irregular Chi-1 / Chi-2 normality scores, RMS-Z score on bonds and angles etc.

The PDB file format has had difficulties, inconsistencies and errors. Corrections can include identifying a meaningful sequence, removal of alternate atoms, correction of nomenclature problems, removal of incomplete residues and spurious waters, addition or removal of water, modelling of missing side chains, optimisation of cysteine bonds, regularisation of bond lengths, bond angles and planarities etc.

This includes methods that calculate poor quality residues. The scoring function to identify poor quality residues may consider residues with bad atoms or atoms with high B-factor, residues in the N- or C-terminal position, adjacent to an unstructured residue, non-canonical residues, glycine and proline (or adjacent to these such residues).
label: Protein structure validation

hasDefinition: Validate some data.
label: Validation

hasDefinition: Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.
label: Molecular model refinement

hasDefinition: Refine or optimise some data model.
label: Optimisation and refinement

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree.
comment: Phylogenetic trees are usually constructed from a set of sequences from which an alignment (or data matrix) is calculated.
label: Phylogenetic inference

hasDefinition: Analyse an existing phylogenetic tree or trees, typically to detect features or make predictions.
comment: Phylgenetic modelling is the modelling of trait evolution and prediction of trait values using phylogeny as a basis.
label: Phylogenetic analysis

hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees.
comment: For example, to produce a consensus tree, subtrees, supertrees, calculate distances between trees or test topological similarity between trees (e.g. a congruence index) etc.
label: Phylogenetic tree comparison

hasDefinition: Edit a phylogenetic tree.
label: Phylogenetic tree editing

hasDefinition: Comparison of a DNA sequence to orthologous sequences in different species and inference of a phylogenetic tree, in order to identify regulatory elements such as transcription factor binding sites (TFBS).
comment: Phylogenetic shadowing is a type of footprinting where many closely related species are used.  A phylogenetic 'shadow' represents the additive differences between individual sequences. By masking or 'shadowing' variable positions a conserved sequence is produced with few or none of the variations, which is then compared to the sequences of interest to identify significant regions of conservation.
label: Phylogenetic footprinting

hasDefinition: Simulate the folding of a protein.
label: Protein folding simulation

hasDefinition: Predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
label: Protein folding pathway prediction

hasDefinition: Map and model the effects of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on protein structure(s).
label: Protein SNP mapping

hasDefinition: Predict the effect of point mutation on a protein structure, in terms of strucural effects and protein folding, stability and function.
comment: Protein SNP mapping maps and modesl the effects of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on protein structure(s).  Methods might predict silent or pathological mutations.
label: Variant effect prediction

hasDefinition: Design molecules that elicit an immune response (immunogens).
label: Immunogen design

hasDefinition: Predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).
label: Zinc finger prediction

hasDefinition: Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.
label: Enzyme kinetics calculation

hasDefinition: Reformat a file of data (or equivalent entity in memory).
label: Formatting

hasDefinition: Test and validate the format and content of a data file.
label: Format validation

hasDefinition: Visualise, plot or render (graphically) biomolecular data such as molecular sequences or structures.
comment: This includes methods to render and visualise molecules.
label: Visualisation

hasDefinition:
Search a sequence database by sequence comparison and retrieve similar sequences.
sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.
comment: This excludes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program).
label: Sequence database search

hasDefinition: Search a tertiary structure database, typically by sequence and/or structure comparison, or some other means, and retrieve structures and associated data.
label: Structure database search

hasDefinition: Search a secondary protein database (of classification information) to assign a protein sequence(s) to a known protein family or group.
label: Protein secondary database search

hasDefinition: Screen a sequence against a motif or pattern database.
label: Motif database search

hasDefinition: Search a database of sequence profiles with a query sequence.
label: Sequence profile database search

hasDefinition: Search a database of transmembrane proteins, for example for sequence or structural similarities.
label: Transmembrane protein database search

hasDefinition: Query a database and retrieve sequences with a given entry code or accession number.
label: Sequence retrieval (by code)

hasDefinition: Query a database and retrieve sequences containing a given keyword.
label: Sequence retrieval (by keyword)

hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.
label: Sequence similarity search

hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.
label: Sequence database search (by motif or pattern)

hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences of a given amino acid composition.
label: Sequence database search (by amino acid composition)

hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences with a specified property, typically a physicochemical or compositional property.
label: Sequence database search (by property)

hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence using a word-based method.
comment: Word-based methods (for example BLAST, gapped BLAST, MEGABLAST, WU-BLAST etc.) are usually quicker than alignment-based methods. They may or may not handle gaps.
label: Sequence database search (by sequence using word-based methods)

hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence using a sequence profile-based method, or with a supplied profile as query.
comment: This includes tools based on PSI-BLAST.
label: Sequence database search (by sequence using profile-based methods)

hasDefinition: Search a sequence database for sequences that are similar to a query sequence using a local alignment-based method.
comment: This includes tools based on the Smith-Waterman algorithm or FASTA.
label: Sequence database search (by sequence using local alignment-based methods)

hasDefinition: Search sequence(s) or a sequence database for sequences that are similar to a query sequence using a global alignment-based method.
comment: This includes tools based on the Needleman and Wunsch algorithm.
label: Sequence database search (by sequence using global alignment-based methods)

hasDefinition: Search a DNA database (for example a database of conserved sequence tags) for matches to Sequence-Tagged Site (STS) primer sequences.
comment: STSs are genetic markers that are easily detected by the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using specific primers.
label: Sequence database search (by sequence for primer sequences)

hasDefinition: Search sequence(s) or a sequence database for sequences which match a set of peptide masses, for example a peptide mass fingerprint from mass spectrometry.
label: Sequence database search (by molecular weight)

hasDefinition: Search sequence(s) or a sequence database for sequences of a given isoelectric point.
label: Sequence database search (by isoelectric point)

hasDefinition: Query a tertiary structure database and retrieve entries with a given entry code or accession number.
label: Structure retrieval (by code)

hasDefinition: Query a tertiary structure database and retrieve entries containing a given keyword.
label: Structure retrieval (by keyword)

hasDefinition: Search a tertiary structure database and retrieve structures with a sequence similar to a query sequence.
label: Structure database search (by sequence)

hasDefinition: Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.
label: Structural similarity search

hasDefinition: Annotate a molecular sequence record with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
label: Sequence annotation

hasDefinition: Annotate a genome sequence with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
label: Genome annotation

hasDefinition: Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.
label: Genome analysis

hasDefinition: Generate the reverse and / or complement of a nucleotide sequence.
hasExactSynonym: Nucleic acid sequence reverse and complement
label: Reverse complement

hasDefinition: Generate a random sequence, for example, with a specific character composition.
label: Random sequence generation

hasDefinition: Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.
label: Restriction digest

comment: This is often followed by calculation of protein fragment masses (http://edamontology.org/operation_0398).
hasDefinition: Cleave a protein sequence into peptide fragments (corresponding to enzymatic or chemical cleavage).
label: Protein sequence cleavage

hasDefinition: Mutate a molecular sequence a specified amount or shuffle it to produce a randomised sequence with the same overall composition.
label: Sequence mutation and randomisation

hasDefinition: Mask characters in a molecular sequence (replacing those characters with a mask character).
comment: For example, SNPs or repeats in a DNA sequence might be masked.
label: Sequence masking

hasDefinition: Cut (remove) characters or a region from a molecular sequence.
label: Sequence cutting

hasDefinition: Create (or remove) restriction sites in sequences, for example using silent mutations.
label: Restriction site creation

hasDefinition: Translate a DNA sequence into protein.
label: DNA translation

hasDefinition: Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).
label: DNA transcription

hasDefinition: Calculate base frequency or word composition of a nucleotide sequence.
label: Sequence composition calculation (nucleic acid)

hasDefinition: Calculate amino acid frequency or word composition of a protein sequence.
label: Sequence composition calculation (protein)

hasDefinition: Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
label: Repeat sequence detection

hasDefinition: Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.
label: Repeat sequence organisation analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein structure.
label: Protein hydropathy calculation (from structure)

hasDefinition: Calculate solvent accessible or buried surface areas in protein or other molecular structures.
comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).
label: Accessible surface calculation

hasDefinition: Analyse the surface properties of proteins or other macromolecules, including surface accessible pockets, interior inaccessible cavities etc.
label: Molecular surface analysis

hasDefinition: Identify clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues in a protein structure.
label: Protein hydropathy cluster calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).
label: Protein dipole moment calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular surface area in proteins and other macromolecules.
label: Molecular surface calculation

hasDefinition: Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein structures.
label: Protein binding site prediction (from structure)

hasDefinition: Analyse the interaction of protein with nucleic acids, e.g. RNA or DNA-binding sites, interfaces etc.
label: Protein-nucleic acid interaction analysis

hasDefinition: Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).
label: Protein peeling

hasDefinition: Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.
label: Protein distance matrix calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.
comment: This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.  It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.
label: Residue distance calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.
label: Contact map calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.
comment: This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.
label: Residue cluster calculation

hasDefinition: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.
comment: The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.
label: Hydrogen bond calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate non-canonical atomic interactions in protein structures.
label: Residue non-canonical interaction detection

hasDefinition: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
label: Ramachandran plot calculation

hasDefinition: Validate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
label: Ramachandran plot validation

hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.
label: Protein molecular weight calculation

hasDefinition: Predict extinction coefficients or optical density of a protein sequence.
label: Protein extinction coefficient calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate pH-dependent properties from pKa calculations of a protein sequence.
label: Protein pKa calculation

hasDefinition: Hydropathy calculation on a protein sequence.
label: Protein hydropathy calculation (from sequence)

hasDefinition: Plot a protein titration curve.
label: Protein titration curve plotting

hasDefinition: Calculate isoelectric point of a protein sequence.
label: Protein isoelectric point calculation

hasDefinition: Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.
label: Protein hydrogen exchange rate calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate hydrophobic or hydrophilic / charged regions of a protein sequence.
label: Protein hydrophobic region calculation

hasDefinition: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).
label: Protein hydropathy calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate aliphatic index (relative volume occupied by aliphatic side chains) of a protein.
label: Protein aliphatic index calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.
label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting

hasDefinition: Predict the stability or globularity of a protein sequence, whether it is intrinsically unfolded etc.
label: Protein globularity prediction

hasDefinition: Predict the solubility or atomic solvation energy of a protein sequence.
label: Protein solubility prediction

hasDefinition: Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.
label: Protein crystallizability prediction

hasDefinition: Detect or predict signal peptides (and typically predict subcellular localisation) of eukaryotic proteins.
label: Protein signal peptide detection (eukaryotes)

hasDefinition: Detect or predict signal peptides (and typically predict subcellular localisation) of bacterial proteins.
label: Protein signal peptide detection (bacteria)

hasDefinition: Predict MHC class I or class II binding peptides, promiscuous binding peptides, immunogenicity etc.
label: MHC peptide immunogenicity prediction

hasDefinition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in protein sequences such as functional sites or regions and secondary structure.
comment: Methods typically involve scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.
label: Protein feature prediction (from sequence)

hasDefinition: Predict antigenic determinant sites (epitopes) in protein sequences.
comment: Epitope mapping is commonly done during vaccine design.
label: Epitope mapping

hasDefinition: Map properties to positions on an biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure), or assemble such an entity from constituent parts.
label: Mapping

hasDefinition: Predict post-translation modification sites in protein sequences.
comment: Methods might predict sites of methylation, N-terminal myristoylation, N-terminal acetylation, sumoylation, palmitoylation, phosphorylation, sulfation, glycosylation, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) modification sites (GPI lipid anchor signals) etc.
label: PTM site prediction

hasDefinition: Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.
comment: Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.
label: Protein signal peptide detection

hasDefinition: Predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences.
label: Protein binding site prediction (from sequence)

hasDefinition: Predict or detect RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.
comment: This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).
label: Nucleic acids-binding site prediction

hasDefinition: Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.
label: Binding site prediction

hasDefinition: Predict protein sites that are key to protein folding, such as possible sites of nucleation or stabilisation.
label: Protein folding site prediction

hasDefinition: Detect or predict cleavage sites (enzymatic or chemical) in protein sequences.
label: Protein cleavage site prediction

hasDefinition: Predict epitopes that bind to MHC class I molecules.
label: Epitope mapping (MHC Class I)

hasDefinition: Predict epitopes that bind to MHC class II molecules.
label: Epitope mapping (MHC Class II)

hasDefinition: Detect, predict and identify whole gene structure in DNA sequences. This includes protein coding regions, exon-intron structure, regulatory regions etc.
label: Whole gene prediction

hasDefinition: Detect, predict and identify genetic elements such as promoters, coding regions, splice sites, etc in DNA sequences.
comment: Methods for gene prediction might be ab initio, based on phylogenetic comparisons, use motifs, sequence features, support vector machine, alignment etc.
label: Gene component prediction

hasDefinition: Detect or predict transposons, retrotransposons / retrotransposition signatures etc.
label: Transposon prediction

hasDefinition: Detect polyA signals in nucleotide sequences.
label: PolyA signal detection

hasDefinition: Detect quadruplex-forming motifs in nucleotide sequences.
comment: Quadruplex (4-stranded) structures are formed by guanine-rich regions and are implicated in various important biological processes and as therapeutic targets.
label: Quadruplex formation site detection

hasDefinition: Find CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence or isochores in genome sequences.
comment: An isochore is long region (> 3 KB) of DNA with very uniform GC content, in contrast to the rest of the genome. Isochores tend tends to have more genes, higher local melting or denaturation temperatures, and different flexibility. Methods might calculate fractional GC content or variation of GC content, predict methylation status of CpG islands etc. This includes methods that visualise CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence, for example plot isochores in a genome sequence.
label: CpG island and isochore detection

hasDefinition: Find and identify restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in (typically) DNA sequences, for example to generate a restriction map.
label: Restriction site recognition

hasDefinition: Identify or predict nucleosome exclusion sequences (nucleosome free regions) in DNA.
label: Nucleosome position prediction

hasDefinition: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
comment: Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.
label: Splice site prediction

hasDefinition: Predict whole gene structure using a combination of multiple methods to achieve better predictions.
label: Integrated gene prediction

hasDefinition: Find operons (operators, promoters and genes) in bacteria genes.
label: Operon prediction

comment: Includes methods that predict whole gene structure using a combination of multiple methods to achieve better predictions.
Methods for gene prediction might be ab initio, based on phylogenetic comparisons, use motifs, sequence features, support vector machine, alignment etc.
hasDefinition: Detect, predict and identify genes or components of genes in DNA sequences, including promoters, coding regions, splice sites, etc.
label: Gene prediction

hasDefinition: Predict protein-coding regions (CDS or exon) or open reading frames in nucleotide sequences.
label: Coding region prediction

hasDefinition: Predict selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in a DNA sequence.
comment: SECIS elements are around 60 nucleotides in length with a stem-loop structure directs the cell to translate UGA codons as selenocysteines.
label: SECIS element prediction

comment: This includes comparative genomics approaches that identify common, conserved (homologous) or synonymous transcriptional regulatory elements.  For example cross-species comparison of transcription factor binding sites (TFBS). Methods might analyse co-regulated or co-expressed genes, or sets of oppositely expressed genes.

This includes promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators, regulatory protein or transcription factor binding sites etc. Methods might be specific to a particular genome and use motifs, word-based / grammatical methods, position-specific frequency matrices, discriminative pattern analysis etc.
hasDefinition: Identify or predict transcriptional regulatory motifs, patterns, elements or regions in DNA sequences.
label: Transcriptional regulatory element prediction

hasDefinition: Predict translation initiation sites, possibly by searching a database of sites.
label: Translation initiation site prediction

hasDefinition: Identify or predict whole promoters or promoter elements (transcription start sites, RNA polymerase binding site, transcription factor binding sites, promoter enhancers etc) in DNA sequences.
comment: Methods might recognize CG content, CpG islands, splice sites, polyA signals etc.
label: Promoter prediction

hasDefinition: Identify, predict or analyse cis-regulatory elements  in DNA sequences (TATA box, Pribnow box, SOS box, CAAT box, CCAAT box, operator etc.) or in RNA sequences (e.g. riboswitches).
comment: Cis-regulatory elements (cis-elements) regulate the expression of genes located on the same strand from which the element was transcribed. Cis-elements are found in the 5' promoter region of the gene, in an intron, or in the 3' untranslated region. Cis-elements are often binding sites of one or more trans-acting factors. They also occur in RNA sequences, e.g. a riboswitch is a region of an mRNA molecule that bind a small target molecule that regulates the gene's activity.
label: cis-regulatory element prediction

hasDefinition: Identify, predict or analyse cis-regulatory elements (for example riboswitches) in RNA sequences.
label: Transcriptional regulatory element prediction (RNA-cis)

hasDefinition: Identify or predict functional RNA sequences with a gene regulatory role (trans-regulatory elements) or targets.
comment: Trans-regulatory elements regulate genes distant from the gene from which they were transcribed.
label: trans-regulatory element prediction

hasDefinition: Identify matrix/scaffold attachment regions (MARs/SARs) in DNA sequences.
comment: MAR/SAR sites often flank a gene or gene cluster and are found nearby cis-regulatory sequences. They might contribute to transcription regulation.
label: S/MAR prediction

hasDefinition: Identify or predict transcription factor binding sites in DNA sequences.
label: Transcription factor binding site prediction

hasDefinition: Identify or predict exonic splicing enhancers (ESE) in exons.
comment: An exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) is 6-base DNA sequence motif in an exon that enhances or directs splicing of pre-mRNA or hetero-nuclear RNA (hnRNA) into mRNA.
label: Exonic splicing enhancer prediction

hasDefinition: Evaluate molecular sequence alignment accuracy.
comment: Evaluation might be purely sequence-based or use structural information.
label: Sequence alignment validation

hasDefinition: Analyse character conservation in a molecular sequence alignment, for example to derive a consensus sequence.
comment: Use this concept for methods that calculate substitution rates, estimate relative site variability, identify sites with biased properties, derive a consensus sequence, or identify highly conserved or very poorly conserved sites, regions, blocks etc.
label: Sequence alignment analysis (conservation)

hasDefinition: Analyse correlations between sites in a molecular sequence alignment.
comment: This is typically done to identify possible covarying positions and predict contacts or structural constraints in protein structures.
label: Sequence alignment analysis (site correlation)

hasDefinition: Identify a correlation, i.e. a statistical relationship between two random variables or two sets of data.
label: Correlation

hasDefinition: Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.
comment: A chimera includes regions from two or more phylogenetically distinct sequences. They are usually artifacts of PCR and are thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to another DNA strand and is subsequently copied to completion in later PCR cycles.
label: Chimera detection

hasDefinition: Detect recombination (hotspots and coldspots) and identify recombination breakpoints in a sequence alignment.
comment: Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.
label: Recombination detection

hasDefinition: Identify insertion, deletion and duplication events from a sequence alignment.
comment: Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.
label: Indel detection

hasDefinition: Predict nucleosome formation potential of DNA sequences.
label: Nucleosome formation potential prediction

hasDefinition: Calculate a thermodynamic property of DNA or DNA/RNA, such as melting temperature, enthalpy and entropy.
label: Nucleic acid thermodynamic property calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.
comment: A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.
label: Nucleic acid melting profile plotting

hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.
comment: A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.
label: Nucleic acid stitch profile plotting

hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.
label: Nucleic acid melting curve plotting

hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.
label: Nucleic acid probability profile plotting

hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.
label: Nucleic acid temperature profile plotting

hasDefinition: Calculate curvature and flexibility / stiffness of a nucleotide sequence.
comment: This includes properties such as.
label: Nucleic acid curvature calculation

hasDefinition: Identify or predict microRNA sequences (miRNA) and precursors or microRNA targets / binding sites in a DNA sequence.
label: miRNA target prediction

hasDefinition: Identify or predict tRNA genes in genomic sequences (tRNA).
label: tRNA gene prediction

hasDefinition: Assess binding specificity of putative siRNA sequence(s), for example for a functional assay, typically with respect to designing specific siRNA sequences.
label: siRNA binding specificity prediction

hasDefinition: Predict secondary structure of protein sequence(s) using multiple methods to achieve better predictions.
label: Protein secondary structure prediction (integrated)

hasDefinition: Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.
label: Protein secondary structure prediction (helices)

hasDefinition: Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
label: Protein secondary structure prediction (turns)

hasDefinition: Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
label: Protein secondary structure prediction (coils)

hasDefinition: Predict cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein sequences.
label: Disulfide bond prediction

hasDefinition: Predict G protein-coupled receptors (GPCR).
label: GPCR prediction

hasDefinition: Analyse G-protein coupled receptor proteins (GPCRs).
label: GPCR analysis

comment: This includes methods that predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
hasDefinition: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.
label: Protein structure prediction

hasDefinition: Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.
label: Ab initio structure prediction

hasDefinition: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
label: Protein modelling

hasDefinition: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.
comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.
label: Molecular docking

hasDefinition: Model protein backbone conformation.
comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.
label: Backbone modelling

hasDefinition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.
comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope).  Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.
label: Side chain modelling

hasDefinition: Model loop conformation in protein structures.
label: Loop modelling

hasDefinition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
comment: Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
label: Protein-ligand docking

hasDefinition: Predict or optimise RNA sequences (sequence pools) with likely secondary and tertiary structure for in vitro selection.
label: RNA inverse folding

hasDefinition: Design (or predict) nucleic acid sequences with specific chemical or physical properties.
label: Nucleic acid design

hasDefinition: Find single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) - single nucleotide change in base positions - between sequences. Typically done for sequences from a high-throughput sequencing experiment that differ from a reference genome and which might, especially by reference to population frequency or functional data, indicate a polymorphism.
comment: This includes functional SNPs for large-scale genotyping purposes, disease-associated non-synonymous SNPs etc.
label: SNP detection

hasDefinition: Generate a physical (radiation hybrid) map of genetic markers in a DNA sequence using provided radiation hybrid (RH) scores for one or more markers.
label: Radiation Hybrid Mapping

hasDefinition: Generate a physical (sequence) map of a DNA sequence showing the physical distance (base pairs) between features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes and other genetic markers.
label: Physical mapping

hasDefinition: Map the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits.
comment: This can involve characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).
label: Functional mapping

hasDefinition: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.
comment: Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).
label: Haplotype mapping

hasDefinition: Calculate linkage disequilibrium; the non-random association of alleles or polymorphisms at two or more loci (not necessarily on the same chromosome).
comment: Linkage disequilibrium is identified where a combination of alleles (or genetic markers) occurs more or less frequently in a population than expected by chance formation of haplotypes.
label: Linkage disequilibrium calculation

hasDefinition: Predict genetic code from analysis of codon usage data.
label: Genetic code prediction

hasDefinition: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.
label: Dot plot plotting

hasDefinition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
label: Pairwise sequence alignment

hasDefinition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.
label: Multiple sequence alignment

hasDefinition: Locally align exactly two molecular sequences.
comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.
label: Pairwise sequence alignment generation (local)

hasDefinition: Globally align exactly two molecular sequences.
comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.
label: Pairwise sequence alignment generation (global)

hasDefinition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.
label: Local alignment

hasDefinition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.
label: Global alignment

hasDefinition: Align two or more molecular sequences with user-defined constraints.
label: Constrained sequence alignment

hasDefinition: Align two or more molecular sequences using multiple methods to achieve higher quality.
label: Consensus-based sequence alignment

hasDefinition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.
label: Tree-based sequence alignment

hasDefinition: Align molecular secondary structure (represented as a 1D string).
label: Secondary structure alignment generation

hasDefinition: Align protein secondary structures.
label: Protein secondary structure alignment generation

hasDefinition: Align RNA secondary structures.
label: RNA secondary structure alignment

hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
label: Pairwise structure alignment

hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
label: Multiple structure alignment

hasDefinition: Align protein tertiary structures.
label: Structure alignment (protein)

hasDefinition: Align RNA tertiary structures.
label: Structure alignment (RNA)

hasDefinition: Locally align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
label: Pairwise structure alignment generation (local)

hasDefinition: Globally align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
label: Pairwise structure alignment generation (global)

hasDefinition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
label: Local structure alignment

hasDefinition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
label: Global structure alignment

hasDefinition: Align exactly two molecular profiles.
comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
label: Profile-profile alignment (pairwise)

hasDefinition: Align two or more molecular profiles.
label: Sequence alignment generation (multiple profile)

hasDefinition: Align exactly two molecular Structural (3D) profiles.
label: 3D profile-to-3D profile alignment (pairwise)

hasDefinition: Align two or more molecular 3D profiles.
label: Structural profile alignment generation (multiple)

hasDefinition: Search and retrieve names of or documentation on bioinformatics tools, for example by keyword or which perform a particular function.
label: Data retrieval (tool metadata)

hasDefinition: Search and retrieve names of or documentation on bioinformatics databases or query terms, for example by keyword.
label: Data retrieval (database metadata)

hasDefinition: Predict primers for large scale sequencing.
label: PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)

hasDefinition: Predict primers for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs).
label: PCR primer design (for genotyping polymorphisms)

hasDefinition: Predict primers for gene transcription profiling.
label: PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)

hasDefinition: Predict primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species.
label: PCR primer design (for conserved primers)

hasDefinition: Predict primers based on gene structure.
label: PCR primer design (based on gene structure)

hasDefinition: Predict primers for methylation PCRs.
label: PCR primer design (for methylation PCRs)

hasDefinition: Sequence assembly by combining fragments using an existing backbone sequence, typically a reference genome.
comment: The final sequence will resemble the backbone sequence. Mapping assemblers are usually much faster and less memory intensive than de-novo assemblers.
label: Mapping assembly

hasDefinition: Sequence assembly by combining fragments without the aid of a reference sequence or genome.
comment: De-novo assemblers are much slower and more memory intensive than mapping assemblers.
label: De-novo assembly

hasDefinition: The process of assembling many short DNA sequences together such thay they represent the original chromosomes from which the DNA originated.
label: Genome assembly

hasDefinition: Sequence assembly for EST sequences (transcribed mRNA).
comment: Assemblers must handle (or be complicated by) alternative splicing, trans-splicing, single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), recoding, and post-transcriptional modification.
label: EST assembly

hasDefinition: Make sequence tag to gene assignments (tag mapping) of SAGE, MPSS and SBS data.
comment: Sequence tag mapping assigns experimentally obtained sequence tags to known transcripts or annotate potential virtual sequence tags in a genome.
label: Sequence tag mapping

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) serial analysis of gene expression (SAGE) data.
label: SAGE data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) massively parallel signature sequencing (MPSS) data.
label: MPSS data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) sequencing by synthesis (SBS) data.
label: SBS data processing

hasDefinition: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
comment: The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.
label: Heat map generation

hasDefinition: Visualise microarray or other expression data.
label: Expression data visualisation

hasDefinition: Analyse one or more gene expression profiles, typically to interpret them in functional terms.
label: Gene expression profile analysis

hasDefinition: Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.
label: Expression profile pathway mapping

hasDefinition: Generate, process or analyse a biological pathway.
label: Pathway analysis

hasDefinition: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate data.
label: Protein secondary structure assignment (from coordinate data)

hasDefinition: Assign secondary structure from circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopic data.
label: Protein secondary structure assignment (from CD data)

hasDefinition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates) from raw X-ray crystallography data.
label: Protein structure assignment (from X-ray crystallographic data)

hasDefinition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates) from raw NMR spectroscopy data.
label: Protein structure assignment (from NMR data)

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree from a specific type of data.
comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different types of data used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
label: Phylogenetic inference (data centric)

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree using a specific method.
comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different computational methods used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
label: Phylogenetic inference (method centric)

hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.
comment: Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.
label: Phylogenetic inference (from molecular sequences)

hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from continuous quantitative character data.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree construction (from continuous quantitative characters)
Phylogenetic tree generation (from continuous quantitative characters)
label: Phylogenetic inference (from continuous quantitative characters)

hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from gene frequency data.
label: Phylogenetic inference (from gene frequencies)

hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.
label: Phylogenetic inference (from polymorphism data)

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.
label: Species tree construction

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing a sequence alignment and searching for the tree with the fewest number of character-state changes from the alignment.
comment: This includes evolutionary parsimony (invariants) methods.
label: Phylogenetic inference (parsimony methods)

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing (or using precomputed) distances between sequences and searching for the tree with minimal discrepancies between pairwise distances.
comment: This includes neighbor joining (NJ) clustering method.
label: Phylogenetic inference (minimum distance methods)

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by relating sequence data to a hypothetical tree topology using a model of sequence evolution.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree construction (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
Phylogenetic tree generation (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
comment: Maximum likelihood methods search for a tree that maximizes a likelihood function, i.e. that is most likely given the data and model. Bayesian analysis estimate the probability of tree for branch lengths and topology, typically using a Monte Carlo algorithm.
label: Phylogenetic inference (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing four-taxon trees (4-trees) and searching for the phylogeny that matches most closely.
label: Phylogenetic inference (quartet methods)

hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.
label: Phylogenetic inference (AI methods)

hasDefinition: Identify a plausible model of DNA substitution that explains a molecular (DNA or protein) sequence alignment.
label: DNA substitution modelling

hasDefinition: Analyse the shape (topology) of a phylogenetic tree.
label: Phylogenetic tree topology analysis

hasDefinition: Apply bootstrapping or other measures to estimate confidence of a phylogenetic tree.
label: Phylogenetic tree bootstrapping

hasDefinition: Construct a "gene tree" which represents the evolutionary history of the genes included in the study.  This can be used to predict families of genes and gene function based on their position in a phylogenetic tree.
comment: Gene trees can provide evidence for gene duplication events, as well as speciation events. Where sequences from different homologs are included in a gene tree, subsequent clustering of the orthologs can demonstrate evolutionary history of the orthologs.
label: Gene tree construction

hasDefinition: Analyse a phylogenetic tree to identify allele frequency distribution and change that is subject to evolutionary pressures (natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow). Identify type of natural selection (such as stabilizing, balancing or disruptive).
comment: Stabilizing/purifying (directional) selection favors a single phenotype and tends to decrease genetic diversity as a population stabilizes on a particular trait, selecting out trait extremes or deleterious mutations. In contrast, balancing selection maintain genetic polymorphisms (or multiple alleles), whereas disruptive (or diversifying) selection favors individuals at both extremes of a trait.
label: Allele frequency distribution analysis

hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.
comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
label: Consensus tree construction

hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to detect subtrees or supertrees.
label: Phylogenetic sub/super tree construction

hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to calculate distances between trees.
label: Phylogenetic tree distances calculation

hasDefinition: Annotate a phylogenetic tree with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
label: Phylogenetic tree annotation

hasDefinition: Predict and optimise peptide ligands that elicit an immunological response.
label: Immunogenicity prediction

hasDefinition: Predict or optimise DNA to elicit (via DNA vaccination) an immunological response.
label: DNA vaccine design

hasDefinition: Reformat (a file or other report of) molecular sequence(s).
label: Sequence formatting

hasDefinition: Reformat (a file or other report of) molecular sequence alignment(s).
label: Sequence alignment formatting

hasDefinition: Reformat a codon usage table.
label: Codon usage table formatting

hasDefinition: Visualise, format or print a molecular sequence alignment.
label: Sequence alignment visualisation

hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render sequence clusters.
label: Sequence cluster visualisation

hasDefinition: Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.
label: Phylogenetic tree visualisation

hasDefinition: Visualise RNA secondary structure, knots, pseudoknots etc.
label: RNA secondary structure visualisation

hasDefinition: Render and visualise protein secondary structure.
label: Protein secondary structure visualisation

hasDefinition: Visualise or render molecular 3D structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.
comment: This includes visualisation of protein secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.
label: Structure visualisation

hasDefinition: Identify and analyse networks of protein interactions.
label: Protein interaction network visualisation

hasDefinition: Draw or visualise a DNA map.
label: Map drawing

hasDefinition: Render a sequence with motifs.
label: Sequence motif rendering

hasDefinition: Draw or visualise restriction maps in DNA sequences.
label: Restriction map drawing

hasDefinition: Draw a linear maps of DNA.
label: DNA linear map rendering

hasDefinition: Draw a circular maps of DNA, for example a plasmid map.
label: Plasmid map drawing

hasDefinition: Visualise operon structure etc.
label: Operon drawing

hasDefinition: Identify folding families of related RNAs.
label: Nucleic acid folding family identification

hasDefinition: Compute energies of nucleic acid folding, e.g. minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
label: Nucleic acid folding energy calculation

hasDefinition: Retrieve existing annotation (or documentation), typically annotation on a database entity.
comment: Use this concepts for tools which retrieve pre-existing annotations, not for example prediction methods that might make annotations.
label: Annotation retrieval

hasDefinition: Compare the functional properties of two or more proteins.
label: Protein function comparison

hasDefinition: Submit a molecular sequence to a database.
label: Sequence submission

hasDefinition: Analyse a known network of gene regulation.
label: Gene regulatory network analysis

hasDefinition: Parse, prepare or load a user-specified data file so that it is available for use.
label: Parsing

hasDefinition: Query a sequence data resource (typically a database) and retrieve sequences and / or annotation.
comment: This includes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program) but not those that perform calculations on the sequence.
label: Sequence retrieval

hasDefinition: Query a tertiary structure data resource (typically a database) and retrieve structures, structure-related data and annotation.
comment: This includes direct retrieval methods but not those that perform calculations on the sequence or structure.
label: Structure retrieval

hasDefinition: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.
comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.
label: Surface rendering

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('accessible surface') for each atom in a structure.
comment: Waters are not considered.
label: Protein atom surface calculation (accessible)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('accessible molecular surface') for each atom in a structure.
comment: Waters are not considered.
label: Protein atom surface calculation (accessible molecular)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('accessible surface') for each residue in a structure.
comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).
label: Protein residue surface calculation (accessible)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('vacuum accessible surface') for each residue in a structure. This is the accessibility of the residue when taken out of the protein together with the backbone atoms of any residue it is covalently bound to.
comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).
label: Protein residue surface calculation (vacuum accessible)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('accessible molecular surface') for each residue in a structure.
comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).
label: Protein residue surface calculation (accessible molecular)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('vacuum molecular surface') for each residue in a structure. This is the accessibility of the residue when taken out of the protein together with the backbone atoms of any residue it is covalently bound to.
comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).
label: Protein residue surface calculation (vacuum molecular)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('accessible molecular surface') for a structure as a whole.
label: Protein surface calculation (accessible molecular)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility ('accessible surface') for a structure as a whole.
label: Protein surface calculation (accessible)

hasDefinition: Calculate for each residue in a protein structure all its backbone torsion angles.
label: Backbone torsion angle calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate for each residue in a protein structure all its torsion angles.
label: Full torsion angle calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate for each cysteine (bridge) all its torsion angles.
label: Cysteine torsion angle calculation

hasDefinition: For each amino acid in a protein structure calculate the backbone angle tau.
comment: Tau is the backbone angle N-Calpha-C (angle over the C-alpha).
label: Tau angle calculation

hasDefinition: Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.
label: Cysteine bridge detection

hasDefinition: Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.
label: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment

hasDefinition: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.
comment: A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.
label: Free cysteine detection

hasDefinition: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
label: Metal-bound cysteine detection

hasDefinition: Calculate protein residue contacts with nucleic acids in a structure.
label: Residue contact calculation (residue-nucleic acid)

hasDefinition: Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.
label: Protein-metal contact calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate ion contacts in a structure (all ions for all side chain atoms).
label: Residue contact calculation (residue-negative ion)

hasDefinition: Detect 'bumps' between residues in a structure, i.e. those with pairs of atoms whose Van der Waals' radii interpenetrate more than a defined distance.
label: Residue bump detection

hasDefinition: Calculate the number of symmetry contacts made by residues in a protein structure.
comment: A symmetry contact is a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.
label: Residue symmetry contact calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate contacts between residues and ligands in a protein structure.
label: Residue contact calculation (residue-ligand)

hasDefinition: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.
comment: Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.
label: Salt bridge calculation

hasDefinition: Predict rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure.
comment: Output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.
label: Rotamer likelihood prediction

hasDefinition: Calculate for each position in a protein structure the chance that a proline, when introduced at this position, would increase the stability of the whole protein.
label: Proline mutation value calculation

hasDefinition: Identify poorly packed residues in protein structures.
label: Residue packing validation

hasDefinition: Validate protein geometry, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.  An example is validation of a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
label: Protein geometry validation

hasDefinition: Extract a molecular sequence from a PDB file.
label: PDB file sequence retrieval

hasDefinition: Identify HET groups in PDB files.
comment: A HET group usually corresponds to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.
label: HET group detection

hasDefinition: Determine for residue the DSSP determined secondary structure in three-state (HSC).
label: DSSP secondary structure assignment

hasDefinition: Reformat (a file or other report of) tertiary structure data.
label: Structure formatting

hasDefinition: Identify poor quality amino acid positions in protein structures.
label: Residue validation

hasDefinition: Query a tertiary structure database and retrieve water molecules.
label: Structure retrieval (water)

hasDefinition: Identify or predict siRNA duplexes in RNA.
label: siRNA duplex prediction

hasDefinition: Refine an existing sequence alignment.
label: Sequence alignment refinement

hasDefinition: Process an EMBOSS listfile (list of EMBOSS Uniform Sequence Addresses).
label: Listfile processing

hasDefinition: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.
label: Sequence file editing

hasDefinition: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a sequence alignment file, such as copying or removal and ordering of sequences.
label: Sequence alignment file processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) physicochemical property data for small molecules.
label: Small molecule data processing

hasDefinition: Search and retrieve documentation on a bioinformatics ontology.
label: Data retrieval (ontology annotation)

hasDefinition: Query an ontology and retrieve concepts or relations.
label: Data retrieval (ontology concept)

hasDefinition: Identify a representative sequence from a set of sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
label: Representative sequence identification

hasDefinition: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a file of molecular tertiary structural data.
label: Structure file processing

hasDefinition: Query a profile data resource and retrieve one or more profile(s) and / or associated annotation.
comment: This includes direct retrieval methods that retrieve a profile by, e.g. the profile name.
label: Data retrieval (sequence profile)

hasDefinition: Perform a statistical data operation of some type, e.g. calibration or validation.
label: Statistical calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.
comment: A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.
label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation

hasDefinition: Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
label: Transmembrane protein visualisation

hasDefinition: An operation performing purely illustrative (pedagogical) purposes.
label: Demonstration

hasDefinition: Query a biological pathways database and retrieve annotation on one or more pathways.
label: Data retrieval (pathway or network)

hasDefinition: Query a database and retrieve one or more data identifiers.
label: Data retrieval (identifier)

hasDefinition: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
label: Nucleic acid density plotting

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) protein interaction data.
label: Protein interaction data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) annotation of some type, typically annotation on an entry from a biological or biomedical database entity.
label: Annotation processing

hasDefinition: Analyse features in molecular sequences.
label: Sequence feature analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse gene expression and regulation data.
label: Gene expression analysis

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) one or more structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) of some type.
label: Structural profile processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) an index of (typically a file of) biological data.
label: Data index processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) some type of sequence profile.
label: Sequence profile processing

hasDefinition: Analyse protein function, typically by processing protein sequence and/or structural data, and generate an informative report.
label: Protein function analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data.  For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.
label: Protein folding analysis

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) data on the physicochemical property of a molecule.
label: Physicochemical property data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) data of a specific type, for example applying analytical methods.
label: Operation (typed)

hasDefinition: Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.
label: Data retrieval

hasDefinition: Retrieve resources from information systems matching a specific information need.
label: Information retrieval

hasDefinition: Perform basic operations on some data or a database.
label: Data handling

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) microarray data.
label: Microarray data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a codon usage table.
label: Codon usage table processing

hasDefinition: Retrieve a codon usage table and / or associated annotation.
label: Data retrieval (codon usage table)

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a gene expression profile.
label: Gene expression profile processing

comment: Analyse gene expression patterns to identify sets of genes that are associated with a specific trait, condition, clinical outcome etc.
Gene sets can be defined beforehand by biological function, chromosome locations and so on.

"Gene set analysis" (often used interchangeably or in an overlapping sense with "gene-set enrichment analysis") refers to the functional analysis (term enrichment) of a differentially expressed set of genes, rather than all genes analysed.
The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.
hasDefinition: Identify classes of genes or proteins that are over or under-represented in a large set of genes or proteins.  For example analysis of a set of genes corresponding to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.
label: Gene-set enrichment analysis

hasDefinition: Analysis of a set of objects, such as genes, annotated with given categories, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain categories within the studied set of objects is revealed.
comment: Categories from a relevant ontology can be used. The input is typically a set of genes or other biological objects, possibly represented by their identifiers, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of categories, each associated with a statistical metric of over-/under-representation within the studied data.
label: Enrichment analysis

hasDefinition: Predict a network of gene regulation.
label: Gene regulatory network prediction

hasDefinition: Generate, analyse or handle a biological pathway or network.
label: Pathway or network processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) RNA tertiary structure data.
label: Structure processing (RNA)

hasDefinition: Predict RNA tertiary structure.
label: RNA structure prediction

hasDefinition: Predict DNA tertiary structure.
label: DNA structure prediction

hasDefinition: Generate, process or analyse phylogenetic tree or trees.
label: Phylogenetic tree processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) protein secondary structure data.
label: Protein secondary structure processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a network of protein interactions.
label: Protein interaction network processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) one or more molecular sequences and associated annotation.
label: Sequence processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a protein sequence and associated annotation.
label: Sequence processing (protein)

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a nucleotide sequence and associated annotation.
label: Sequence processing (nucleic acid)

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a sequence cluster.
label: Sequence cluster processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a sequence feature table.
label: Feature table processing

hasDefinition: Classify G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) into families and subfamilies.
label: GPCR classification

hasDefinition: Predict G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) coupling selectivity.
label: GPCR coupling selectivity prediction

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a protein tertiary structure.
label: Structure processing (protein)

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility for each atom in a structure.
comment: Waters are not considered.
label: Protein atom surface calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility for each residue in a structure.
label: Protein residue surface calculation

hasDefinition: Calculate the solvent accessibility of a structure as a whole.
label: Protein surface calculation

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a molecular sequence alignment.
label: Sequence alignment processing

hasDefinition: Identify or predict protein-protein binding sites.
label: Protein-protein binding site prediction

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a molecular tertiary structure.
label: Structure processing

hasDefinition: Annotate a DNA map of some type with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
label: Map annotation

hasDefinition: Retrieve information on a protein.
label: Data retrieval (protein annotation)

hasDefinition: Retrieve a phylogenetic tree from a data resource.
label: Data retrieval (phylogenetic tree)

hasDefinition: Retrieve information on a protein interaction.
label: Data retrieval (protein interaction annotation)

hasDefinition: Retrieve information on a protein family.
label: Data retrieval (protein family annotation)

hasDefinition: Retrieve information on an RNA family.
label: Data retrieval (RNA family annotation)

hasDefinition: Retrieve information on a specific gene.
label: Data retrieval (gene annotation)

hasDefinition: Retrieve information on a specific genotype or phenotype.
label: Data retrieval (genotype and phenotype annotation)

hasDefinition: Compare the architecture of two or more protein structures.
label: Protein architecture comparison

hasDefinition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
label: Protein architecture recognition

hasDefinition: Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.
label: Structure classification

hasDefinition: The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.
label: Molecular dynamics

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a molecular secondary structure.
label: Secondary structure processing

hasDefinition: Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.
label: Helical wheel drawing

hasDefinition: Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.
label: Topology diagram drawing

hasDefinition: Compare protein tertiary structures.
comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.
label: Protein structure comparison

hasDefinition: Compare protein secondary structures.
label: Protein secondary structure comparison

hasDefinition: Predict the subcellular localisation of a protein sequence.
comment: The prediction might include subcellular localisation (nuclear, cytoplasmic, mitochondrial, chloroplast, plastid, membrane etc) or export (extracellular proteins) of a protein.
label: Subcellular localisation prediction

hasDefinition: Calculate contacts between residues in a protein structure.
label: Residue contact calculation (residue-residue)

hasDefinition: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acid residues.
label: Hydrogen bond calculation (inter-residue)

hasDefinition: Predict the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
label: Protein interaction prediction

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) codon usage data.
label: Codon usage data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a network of gene regulation.
label: Gene regulatory network processing

hasDefinition: Generate, process or analyse a biological pathway or network.
label: Pathway or network analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse SAGE, MPSS or SBS experimental data, typically to identify or quantify mRNA transcripts.
label: Sequencing-based expression profile data analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse raw microarray data.
label: Microarray raw data analysis

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) nucleic acid sequence or structural data.
label: Nucleic acid analysis

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) protein sequence or structural data.
label: Protein analysis

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) molecular sequence data.
label: Sequence data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) molecular structural data.
label: Structural data processing

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) text.
label: Text processing

hasDefinition: Analyse a protein sequence alignment, typically to detect features or make predictions.
label: Protein sequence alignment analysis

hasDefinition: Analyse a protein sequence alignment, typically to detect features or make predictions.
label: Nucleic acid sequence alignment analysis

hasDefinition: Compare two or more nucleic acid sequences.
label: Nucleic acid sequence comparison

hasDefinition: Compare two or more protein sequences.
label: Protein sequence comparison

hasDefinition: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.
label: DNA back-translation

hasDefinition: Edit or change a nucleic acid sequence, either randomly or specifically.
label: Sequence editing (nucleic acid)

hasDefinition: Edit or change a protein sequence, either randomly or specifically.
label: Sequence editing (protein)

hasDefinition: Generate a nucleic acid sequence by some means.
label: Sequence generation (nucleic acid)

hasDefinition: Generate a protein sequence by some means.
label: Sequence generation (protein)

hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence.
comment: Various nucleic acid sequence analysis methods might generate a sequence rendering but are not (for brevity) listed under here.
label: Nucleic acid sequence visualisation

hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a protein sequence.
comment: Various protein sequence analysis methods might generate a sequence rendering but are not (for brevity) listed under here.
label: Protein sequence visualisation

hasDefinition: Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
label: Nucleic acid structure comparison

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) nucleic acid tertiary structure data.
comment: http://edamontology.org/operation_2481
label: Structure processing (nucleic acid)

hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) a DNA map of some type.
label: Map data processing

hasDefinition: Build clusters of similar structures, typically using scores from structural alignment methods.
label: Structure clustering

hasDefinition: Generate a physical DNA map (sequence map) from analysis of sequence tagged sites (STS).
comment: An STS is a short subsequence of known sequence and location that occurs only once in the chromosome or genome that is being mapped. Sources of STSs include 1. expressed sequence tags (ESTs), simple sequence length polymorphisms (SSLPs), and random genomic sequences from cloned genomic DNA or database sequences.
label: Sequence tagged site (STS) mapping

hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.
label: Protein fragment weight comparison

hasDefinition: Compare the physicochemical properties of two or more proteins (or reference data).
label: Protein property comparison

hasDefinition: Compare two or more molecular secondary structures.
label: Secondary structure comparison

hasDefinition: Generate a Hopp and Woods plot of antigenicity of a protein.
label: Hopp and Woods plotting

hasDefinition: Generate a view of clustered quantitative data, annotated with textual information.
label: Cluster textual view generation

comment: In the case of microarray data, visualise clustered gene expression data as a set of profiles, where each profile shows the gene expression values of a cluster across samples on the X-axis.
hasDefinition: Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.
label: Clustering profile plotting

hasDefinition: Generate a dendrograph of raw, preprocessed or clustered expression (e.g. microarray) data.
label: Dendrograph plotting

hasDefinition: Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.
label: Proximity map plotting

hasDefinition: Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.
hasExactSynonym: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering
label: Dendrogram visualisation

comment: Examples for visualization are the distribution of variance over the components, loading and score plots.

The use of Principal Component Analysis (PCA), a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables on the atomic positional fluctuations, helps to separate the configurational space in two subspaces: an essential subspace containing relevant motions, and another one containing irrelevant local fluctuations.
hasDefinition: Visualize the results of a principal component analysis (orthogonal data transformation).  For example, visualization of the principal components (essential subspace) coming from a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on the trajectory atomistic coordinates of a molecular structure.
label: Principal component visualisation

comment: Comparison of two sets of quantitative data such as two samples of gene expression values.
hasDefinition: Render a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along two axes; the pattern of the points reveals any correlation.
label: Scatter plot plotting

hasDefinition: Visualise gene expression data where each band (or line graph) corresponds to a sample.
label: Whole microarray graph plotting

hasDefinition: Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.
label: Treemap visualisation
